content:
Posted: September 3, 2013
												As far as RTS's go, I dont like them. Too many of them do their systems too incorrectly, or just dont plain make any logical sense, or reason. Dawn of War (all the expansion packs, consider this a recommendation for Dawn of War + all of the expansions), does some critical things right, which makes it stand out from the crowd. First, it actually focuses on strategy for the most part. Instead of spamming 1000 tanks at your enemy (im looking at you Ruse), you actually have chose a limited number of units to bring into battle. Meaning, every man, tank, and resourse is valuble, and losing any of the above can cost you the battle. This tension, and balencing on the brink of death keeps tension high, as players must constantly have to outdo their opponent on a mental capacity, not necessarily on a quanitative capacity. This conbined with some rather unique in game mechanics, such as morale, means interesting strategies can arise, when those similar would fall flat in other RTS's.And secondly, the game is able to keep a consistent feeling, tone, and atmosphere. Even for a strategy game, this is important, nothing takes you out of a game more than an interface, so even immersing the mission select screen in 40k does its job. Everything is plastered with 40k jargon and logic, a dark universe of war, death, and betrayal. As well, the game itself feels fitting, with you not taking resources, just getting requisition points to send in more troops, as you are successful in conquest, just as an example of many different things the game does right.The game is fitting, and is able to keep a consistent feel to gameplay and atmosphere. For this, I must heartily recommend Dawn of War to RTS fans, you will not be let down.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I wont discuss the mechanics or the diversity.  Look to the other comments for that♥♥♥♥♥♥  I am simply giving a story and some true as Khorne is bloodthirsty observations.  As I begin remember that in the future, there is only war.  One must choose his battlecry well.  For the Greater Good.One of the best RTS games out there.  Nothing quite beats some of the moments the game brings on.  The following is a part of a game I did (in skirmish) against the ai with 6 bots vs just my ai partner and I:As I looked at my minimap, I realized my buddy's base was quickly getting overwhelmed.  His outer defenses were obliterated not a few minutes ago, and yet the enemy was closing in around his HQ.  He was building guardsmen as quickly as he could but the onslaught of orks, chaos space marines, and necrons were too much.  His commander made a valiant last stand, but it was in vain...I was then alone.I scrutinized my defenses and realized I was lacking.  I quickly built many turrets as my first line of defense with some space marines around a pass that funneled the enemy forces down and caused them to lose some of the advantage of numbers.  My second line were multiple heavy tanks with melee infantry further behind the pass.  The purpose of this line was a bullet magnet while my base spit out as many units as I could for a heroic last stand.  The third line was whoever else was left at the time the other two lines fell.  As I checked my units upgrades and made sure they had all they could have, then I saw a red tide on the minimap.  I realized the Emperor would be seeing us soon in the next life.As the enemy forces through themselves at the turrets, I couldn't help but realize the corpses of the dead.  The game has an option that leaves almost all the corpses on the field, and I recommend to turn it on to the max as it adds satisfaction to the price your men are paying.  The turrets and supporting infantry could only hold on for so long.  Before the line was breached I was in about a 7:1 kd ratio.  After the line was broken, it became a 1:1.  I zoomed in close for a final look at these men, and I grinned for I knew we would all be joining him soon.  The second line held for about half the time.  The third and final line consisted of my commander and everyone else that had not died.  I waited until the enemy was within weapon's range, then I lit them up with artillery, orbital strikes, and the last two flyers I had.  Then, my men charged.  They went down valiantly with many enemies dead in the process.  I knew there was no chance for victory from the very beginning, but I watched as my commander made his final defiant yell, I was sad there was never a chance.  I was fighting for time, and I got a lot of time.  We fought until the final drop of blood was spilt, until the final breath was exhaled, until the fat♥♥♥♥♥ho sang, until the bitter end.  These are the moments that define gaming, not the scripted ones that everyone encounters, but the ones that are player-made.  The game modes where the goal is to kill the enemy commander, and you are completely surrounded on all sides and you make a final charge to kill him to gain victory, and you see your numbers fall from 30 to 23 to 14 to 6 until all you have left is two guardsmen (they die sooooooo easily) and a tank that has a third of its health left and you win.  You win against all the odds, and you smirk at the trail of the men that died for victory.  I cannot tell you of all the awesomeness that is this game.  Go get it.IN THE GRIM DARKNESS OF THE FAR FUTURE THERE IS ONLY WAR.  AND A METRIC♥♥♥♥♥♥TON (THAT IS A ♥♥♥♥ING MEASUREMENT) OF ENEMY INFANTRY.

												Stop reading this, buy all the DOW games. Look don't ask just buy it, you won't regret it. In particular buy the master collection, i'll explain why below:Why buy Master? Master comes with all the factions fully playable in multiplayer and single player skirmishes, that's why. Simply download, install and play all of them at least once and you have full access to everything. You get 9-10 factions all together, 9-10 factions that all play /very/ differently with their own fun and unique tactics.so look i'll do a review just for fun, but hurry up and buy it, you won't regret it:Pros: Fun open campaign: None of this boring DOW:II campaigns where its "OH LOOK ITS THE SPACE MARRINES WE'RE SO SPACE MARINEY"Diverse factions: Space Marines, Imperial Guads, Necrons, Tau, Eldar etc don't play alike, at all. They each play very differently and are relatively balanced. Try them out they're also all flavoured differently so if you're into BDSM I suggest playing Dark Eldar. If you're a pyromaniac who loves girls with big guns, may I direct you to the Sisters of Battle. If you're a ♥♥♥♥♥ I will direct you to the Space Marines. If you're a ♥♥♥♥♥ with some angst I would direct you to the Chaos Space Marines.Multiplayer: By gaming standards this game is old, but there is still an active multiplayer community, thats more then DOW:II can really say.Army Painter: Ever look at your GLORIOUS IMPERIAL GUARD WITH BALLS OF ♥♥♥♥ING STEEL and say, gee they look stupid, they NEED TO BE ♥♥♥♥ING PINK, well guess what: You can customize the colour schemes for your army, if you want to create an army of Pink Necrons or Imperial Guards from the Planet majesta then go on ahead and do it.Replay value: This game has a lot of replay value in multiplayer and campaigns. CONS:Graphics are a bit dated, but thats okay, it means it can run on your rig.the multiplayer can be difficult at times, i've lost sometimes very fast.NO Tyranids. I think there are mods that fix this but I don't bother with them, I hated the Tyranids in DOW:II OP AS♥♥♥♥♥♥ This might be a pro, idk.Guides are currently "Meh" on the steam community section, most of them being troll guides.Some  SPESS MEHREENS (Space Marines) chapters are not represented beyond some pre-made skins for them. So if you're expecting to bring out some Space Wolves the best you'll get is some light blue power armour for your  SPESS MEHREENS. But, who cares they're  SPESS MEHREENS.Final notes: IF you're still reading this you're wasting your time when you could be burning the heretics and slaying the Xenos in the name of the EMPRAH. But in all seriousness Soulstorm is a recommended one to buy along with any other expansion as soulstorm is where peep's go to play multiplayer. But Soulstorm only comes with Dark Eldar and Sisters of battle. See other expansions for their factions. Or buy the Master collection.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												The squad system revolutionized RTS. Nothing has been quite the same since.The addition of two races in the final expansion of what I daresay is the RTS of the decade was not surprising, but maybe raised a few eyebrows. To some, updating this game with more content seemed a waste - why bother spending time on adding things to a game whose graphics could easily be dismissed as much too old for the current era?And yet, Dawn of War remains timeless, and so does this expansion. A sprawling campaign, active online community (even now, in a time of "superior" graphics and smoother gameplay), and a well thought-out set of mechanics that ensured every race had their advantages and disadvantages, some canceling each other out, others complementing each other, to create a blend of nine staggeringly complex races.The learning curve of some races is high, and low for some others. There's something in this game for anyone who's even thought about playing an RTS. Mastering a race is, in itself, a reward. And a set of over a hundred maps, ranging from tiny two-person maps to sprawling eight-person arenas, will only add to the experience of doing so.Overall, 10/10. Solid soundtrack as always, decent enough graphics (they were ahead for their time when the first game was released) without taking too much of a toll on your system, eye-opening variation in mechanics for all nine races.

Posted: October 21, 2014
												This game is just simply badass and awesome. The campaign is good, there is many races and the AI is really challenging on insane. With mods this game shines like gold (especially the Ultimate Apocalypse mod which I really recommend). The gameplay itself is smooth and well done-each unit is important, 1 building, 1 research, 1 Commander can change the tide of battle but you're gonna need a really strong processor for it if you wanna run the game with hundreds of units on the field, otherwise you will get command lag. The game's graphics are great for a game engine that came out in 2004 (you can even use SweetFX, ENB or other stuff like that to improve it even further). I didn't even mentoin that you can improve the game's graphics and detail on units just by typing some simple commands in the Local.ini and the game starts looking SO GOOD. The only real con for this game is that you have to buy first 3 Dawn of War games to unlock all races for the multiplayer but its damn well worth it.10/10       =====MUST BUY=====

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Do you know when you truly love a game? When almost 12 years after it's launch, the giddy excitement of running home from work to play it never actually wore off.Don't let my playtime fool you, I owned the boxed versions of these games loooong before they were in my Steam account and have invested literally THOUSANDS of hours into this game. I was always kind of interested in 40K, having roomates who played the tabletop when I was younger and reading the odd comic here and there, but THIS was the game that turned me into a 40K fanboy and opened me up to the whole universe.Now before I go any further, if you want the definitive version of Dawn of War for its best balance in both mutliplayer and a better designed single player campaign then buy Dark Crusade. It was the pinnacle of the series. There are two reasons why I play Soulstorm more than Dark Crusade, the first is that the multiplayer community seems to be much more active on SS than it is on DC, the second and infinitely more important reason is what the games community simply refers to by two letters......UA.The "Ultimate Apocalypse" mod for Soul Storm or "UA" for short, has become the absolute best Warhammer 40k game ever made. The following are just the things that I personally like about the mod, but doesn't even tip the iceburg for what it encompasses :-expands the maps and removes level caps so the truly epic 40K battles can expand in scope-introduces new races including Inquisition, Chaos Daemons, Tyranids and more...-introduced tons of new untis for exsiting races-new buildings, superweapons and tech trees to explore for all races-better balancing than vanilla for multiplayer-constant updates and new content all the timeand of course......TITANS!!!!The only thing I can hope for (because lets not kid ourselves, Relic is working on DoW 3) is that they make the next game much more like UA in design and get away from the smaller tactical stuff they did with DoW 2.All in all this is my favorite game of all time and the first and to date ONLY time I will score a game with a perfect 10/10. Bravo Relic and the UA team,  everyone's got a fave....and you made mine.

number of helpful: 43 of 55 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Back in 2004 Relic unleashed the original Dawn of War, a real-time strategy game, and established its distinctive, polished take on control point capture gameplay. The game shifted focus from base building to managing units in the field and provided an enjoyable method of resource collection. It didn't hurt that it was based in a universe as rich as Games Workshop's Warhammer 40,000 fiction, where blood, beastly deeds, and brutal combat are commonplace.Since then we've seen two expansions, Winter Assault and the superb Dark Crusade. While Dark Crusade changed quite a bit about the single-player campaign, the third expansion, Soulstorm, doesn't offer much that's surprising. Naturally there's more content like two new armies, a retooled persistent campaign, flying units, and more maps, but there isn't much that drastically alters how players experience the game. That being said, it still features fantastically addictive RTS gameplay, even if the formula seems a little tired at this point, particularly after Relic advanced their capture point mechanic with Company of Heroes in 2006.The new factions include the Sisters of Battle, a predominantly female band of holy crusaders, and the Dark Eldar, a twisted version of the Eldar. Though they manage to retain their own distinct personalities and unique elements of play, things are really starting to blend together with a total of nine armies in the game. Despite the overcrowded selection, the two additions are nevertheless entertaining. The Sisters' strength seems to be with their infantry groups, augmented by the ability to attach certain units for added firepower, abilities, or healing. Several of their unit groupings can be customized with weaponry to bust up other infantry, puncture vehicles, and more rapidly destroy buildings, making them effective throughout the course of a game. Limiting some of their unit abilities is a new resource called faith, generated by upgrading capture point structures with special additions. Building and maintaining faith doesn't result in any kind of dramatically different play style, however.With the Dark Eldar you get a different kind of resource to worry about: soul essence. Several units possess a harvest ability, which when activated consumes the essence contained in the corpses of enemies. Reaping soul essence on the battlefield is somewhat pointless, however, as you can have your unit cap management structures back in your base constantly spawn bodies. By assigning a builder unit or two to harvest, a constant stream of the stuff is ensured, so there's little strategy to the whole mechanic, making it feel more like busywork. With enough essence, Dark Eldar players can unleash spells on foes ranging from a few area-of-effect damage strikes to morale modifiers.The rest of the armies have received minor tweaks, the most notable being flying units. After toying around with them, the units don't feel like they've been integrated very well. Though they can hover across terrain, they don't seem to do much to alter how you'd play had they not been included. Fans of Dark Crusade's persistent campaign will almost certainly enjoy the single-player here, which is basically the same thing. Instead of a single continent the territory for Soulstorm is broken up across several planets, though the number of contestable provinces isn't all that much more. The Sisters of Battle get the added ability to establish forward bases with their command point spoils and the Dark Eldar aren't restricted by the paths to hop between planets like other armies are. As in Dark Crusade, you gain access to special gear and powered-up units that accompany heroes into each battle and can reinforce territory using requisition points gained from expanding across the map.Tying together the campaign is a flimsy exposition describing why all the races are converging on this section of the galaxy. To say it's compelling is to lie. More narrative is delivered as you assault stronghold provinces and have to deal with several special objectives to wipe enemies off the map for good, but you'll find more character and personality in each race's unit acknowledgements than in the cut-scenes. Soulstorm is almost entirely about the combat.And the combat is enjoyable, helped along by the audio and visual elements that effectively convey the carnage and blind aggression Warhammer 40K is known for. Units and vehicles closely resemble their table top equivalents and their personalities come across clearly through animations and often hilarious unit speech. The Dark Eldar builder unit's terrified responses to construction and movement commands were a personal favorite.The VerdictSoulstorm's development was handled mostly by Iron Lore (the recently-closed developer best known for Titan Quest) and they've produced a solid expansion. The main issue here is just that everything feels so familiar. While the game still plays quite well and Warhammer 40K fans will surely appreciate all the unit designs for the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar, too little has been done to enliven the experience, particularly when compared to what Dawn of War's previous expansion, Dark Crusade, did for the game.+Still Exciting Campaign Mode+Two More Races Mean More Fun+Aircraft And Wargear Expansion-Balancing Issues-Not Much New Things To Offer Review Score: 71/100

number of helpful: 23 of 25 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Multiplayer now Gamespy free! (Steamworks)(Single player review) Every species and faction from the previous Dawn of War main game + Expansions, with two new factions and a campaign that is almost a copy of Dark Crusade. Which is a good thing, considering how much fun Dark Crusade was with the added burden of choices and a persistent battlefield. The two new factions possess enough uniqueness to make them viable alternatives to the series mainstays. I've personally come to prefer the Sisters of Battle over Chaos due to the Sister's faith mechanic, where faith serves as a resource for various units to use for healing and attack bonuses in addition to whatever normal abilities the units possess. The Sisters also have a much greater reliance on melee and flame-based weapons compared to many of the other factions. I personally have no interest in the Dark Eldar, but the new faction's soul-harvesting mechanic dosen't sound like anything the other factions have.My only real complaint agianst Soulstorm is that the additions to the single player campain seem poorly planed. Firstly, there's very little in the way of additions from Dark Crusade, but this isn't automatically a bad thing. What is troublesome, however, is that the main change, a move from a single planet battlefield to multiple, dosen't allow for zoom or any perspective changes. This means you may encounter difficulty seeing areas of the main battle map, where you view your territories and the territories of your enemies, at higher resolutions. Some tactical planning may be hampered by this, but this is not a large complaint.If you have any interest in 40k, or if you are tired of Dark Crusade, or even if you just want to see a mostly-female (not all female, for some reason) human faction (I can't tell when it comes to the Eldar, but I guess they're female, too), pick up this game.  You don't need the other Dawn of War 1 games unless you really like space marine (Dawn of War base game) or Imperial Guard (Winter Assualt) plotlines. You will need the other games to unlock the other factions in multiplayer (already have all factions unlocked for any and all single player aspects).Gameplay:


YouTube™ Video: Glance: Dawn of War Soulstorm (Sisters of Battle) 

			Views: 112		

			Gameplay from the last expansion to Dawn of War, focusing heavily on my new favorite faction, the Sisters of Battle. Steam link: http://store.steampowered.com/app/9450/

												One of my favorite RTS-games. Sadly, the campaign is not as epic as the one from Dark Crusade but you don't care about that. Maybe you're like me, and asked yourself "Dark Crusade was fun and all - but where's the flamers at?". Luckily, your prayers were answered in Soulstorm by introducing Sisters of Battle. Have you ever wanted to burn the enemies of the Imperium? Have you ever wished you could wield a tank with spinning flamers? Have you ever said to yourself "I wish there would be a race that would be EXTREMELY devoted to the God-Emperor of Man! Even more than the Space Marines!"? then you'll love Sisters of Battle. Wield flamers on your troops, flamers on your tanks, flamers on your open-topped walkers, flamers on your turrets - all while God-Emperor boosts your units' health and makes their ammo deadlier thanks to Acts of Faith exclusive to SoB.10/10 would flame for Emperor again.

												It's a classic. What else is there to say? This game as aged very well. Lots of content, this game respects the lore of Warhammer 40k and it's awesome. The RTS play of this game might not be the most MLG one, but sure can give you some stressful games where you're on the edge. The battles are absolutly epic with a fairly big scale when played 4v4. The style of play can be comparable to age of empires, but the units are in squads. Unlike his younger brother, DoW 2, it makes economy and macro gestion really important and battles of a bigger scale.If you're looking for a classic RTS with a great, already established lore and some epic action, this game would be a good choice.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Compared to Dawn of War - Dark Crusade:+ it has two more factions to play as (Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar)+ it adds an air unit to all existing factions+ it's the latest Dawn of War game, so it comes with the most up to date "balance patch" for multiplayer- pretty much everything elseThe main issue with Soulstorm is, that the developers basically copied the successful campaign mode from Dark Crusade and only made it worse (I assume they didn't spend too much money on this installment anymore). The new commanders, their writing and voice acting is horrible compared to Dark Crusade. I mean the Necron Lord not only *talks* (whereas in DC, the talking was done cleverly by a humanoid hybrid Pariah, the other Necron units remaining almost always silent), he talks like he's got lung cancer. The Space Marines' Boreale lacked so much charisma that they had him canonically killed off after this game. All the other new commanders are basically just copied but worse versions of their Dark Crusade equivalents. The only two exceptions are - the Imperial Guard commander, Vance Stubbs, who's still worse than Alexander from Dark Crusade (especially in terms of voice acting), but at least he's got some character of his own - and the Ork commander, Warboss Gorgutz, because he's the only one returning from Dark Crusade.But even writing/character/likability/voice acting aside, the campaign is worse in gameplay aspects as well. For some reason, the developers felt the need to "rebalance" the gameplay portion of the campaign, even though it's single player only. That means that everything got toned down - almost all of the Commanders' best upgrades got nerfed. As if that wasn't enough, defense missions are also extremely painful now. Why? Because in Dark Crusade, all sturctures that you've built in a mission would remain on the map the next time you play. That was mostly to compensate for the fact that you don't start out with your Commander/Honor Guard as you would normally when attacking. In Soulstorm, they removed that, so every single time, all the structures you've built magically disappear from the map after you win. Having to play the same two-three maps over and over and over again on the enemy's turn when he's attacking you, always starting from just your HQ and your stationed units there is incredibly boring and time consuming. And to top it all off, they also nerfed the bonuses you get - there are no longer any specials "out there" on the map for you to get, only Honor Guard. Some tiny production bonuses are also scattered around the map, but they're not even worth the time, really. Instead, every faction starts with its own special bonus that the others get after conquering their HQ. That sounds like nice balance on paper, but it's not really, since many of the factions start with useless arbirtrary stuff (Tau, Necrons), absolutely worthless stuff (Chaos), while the downright overpowered specials, of course, belong to the Eldar and the Sisters of Battle.Overall, a good game for what it is, and if you want to play the multiplayer, but if you're looking for a nice single player campaign experience, I'd recommend Dark Crusade instead.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												This is definitely one of the best RTS games out there, have been playing it for 8 years now (not all the time) but I have not found any RTS that matches this. here are a few reasons why.1. The huge range of units and races:Ok so most RTS games will default to 3 or 4 factions, this one however (as long as you have all the other expansions and core game) gives you up to 9 playable races. and its not like their all similar either, each race is completely unique and different.2. no rule restrictions:So some RTS games I have recently had a look at will limit rules, for instance you cannot set your own teams, map position etc. This has a wide range of rules you can change to your way of playing.3. The huge ammount of maps:I have looked at some of the new RTS games, and one thing that turns me off is the map selection. They will have about 10-20 maps, usually with 1 map being an 8 player (if they even have 8 players allowed) this game however has over 100 maps! With both even maps for competitive matches or more unfair maps for free for alls, 2v2v2's 2v2v2v2's etc.4. The game play is both fun to watch, and very competitive (suits any style of play)Even after 4+ years of playing this game, I still learn new things, tactics, this game is very balanced, and there is no issue of players spamming mass of units to win.If you do get this game and enjoy it, I strongly reccomend you download the supermod 'Ultimate Apocalypse mod' The latest version is 'The Hunt Begins'Here is a link to the group if you were interested: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/uamg

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Dawn of War is one of the best RTS games ever made, and Soulstorm lives up to the high expectations set by the previous expansions in the series. At first I was reluctant to buy it because I was wary of the air units and tedious campaign I had heard about, but I'm glad I didn't let that dissuade me. The two new races aren't as different as the Necron and Tau were for Dark Crusade but they are still well made, and the air units are actually nice; I never had to change my preferred strategy or tactics in order to accommodate their addition. Overall Soulstorm is much more balanced as well, no more getting rushed by Necrons in the first few minutes of a game and being able to do almost nothing about it.When you eventually get bored of the vanilla game, the modding community is still quite active for a game of its age. Many people like the Ultimate Apocalypse mod, and while it is fun and adds some cool units, it's poorly balanced and has some features that just make the game feel cheap at times (ork squad cap in the hundreds, feeble necrons, armageddon-like technologies, for example). I recommed downloading Firestorm over Kaurava instead for a much more polished, balanced, and true-to-codex experience that adds many new units and some cool strategic mechanics to the game. I've been playing the game almost daily for weeks now thanks to the mods, they're well worth it.TL,DR: If you have doubts about getting this game but you loved the past expansions, buy it now. The vanilla is great, mods make it even better.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												I've been playing this game for years, an excellent example of what can be achieved in RTS and does a pretty good job with balance, and the campaign is solid too. After that, there are great customisations, upgrades and a wide variety of maps if you're more interested in skirmishes or playing online. I haven't messed around too much with mods but Ultimate Apocalypse is amazing.Pros- Wide variety in playable armies, each one has unique aspects and you can play the campagin with each faction, knowing that it will feel like a different experience.- Large variety of unit types and styles of battling, represents this side of the warhammer 40k world pretty well- Base battles in the campaign are awesome, often very challenging but are really fun in my opinion- The progression throughout a battle is really well done, it also challenges you to be efficient in the way you prioritise the buildings you go for firstCons- Necrons are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥br>- I preferred it when all the campaign battles were HQ destruction victories, sometimes the take and hold gets really annoying since you have to wait an extra 10-15 minutes for a game to end- Stealth can feel a little unbalanced at times, if you have a small army and they lose their stealth detection unit, you'll be completely screwed against EldarOverall, I love this game. The issues I've mentioned are quite minor and the positives far outweigh the negatives. Even if you aren't familiar with warhammer this game will be really enjoyable to you.9/10

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												This is probably the best RTS and I played most of them from Dune 2 to Starcraft 2. If you could not stand your armies being obliterated in 2 seconds like in Starcraft 2 you might try this game. Battles take time and you can have fun even if you loose. The resources comes from points that you need to control so there is no turtling and there is constant action all around.++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++The pluses: + Best RTS gameplay  + Nice campaigns with cool, good quality videos (worth to get all expansions for all campaigns)  + Graphics are good even today and the art style is fantastic  + Cool animations when you get special kills. Throwing, cutting slices, blood split around...  + Awesome voice acting and great sound affects  + Good music  + 9 distinctive races in multiplayer - (you must get all expansions to get them all to play against humans, but in skirmish against AI all are present and available) Some with different resource mechanics.# Orcs - green skin brute killers that like axes and bigga guns "Orkz Orkz" # Space marines - genetically modified humans with awesome mechs and tanks "For the Emperor" # Chaos - tainted space marines with Demons on their side "Do you hear the voices too?" # Eldar - Elf-like aliens with sophisticated technology # Imperial Guard - Imperial Army that rely on spamming large masses of soldiers and tanks # Tau - advanced race fighting "For the Greater Good" # Necrons - living metal organisms # Sisters of Battle - female order dedicated to worship of the Emperor "To the Emperor, my life; to Him, my death." # Dark Eldar - Eldars tainted by Chaos that harvest Soul Essence from fallen opponents  + Many game modes for (1v1, 2v2, 3v3, 4v4, Free Fall All) and settings (control and hold 50% of points, 66%, Annihilate etc.)  + Pretty fast to find a game in lobby (even for 8 players)  + Still living community+ Lots of mods (some add new factions and many new units)------------------------------------------------------The minuses:- code for servers is bugged (sometimes players drop at beginning because out of sync)  - 1v1 Automatch sometimes take some time to find opponent (but instead you can create game in lobby and someone will get in pretty fast)  - Automatching for bigger number of players (more than 1v1) might take A LOT of time (but like I sad before, games in lobby are filled fast)  - Stats displayed for players are bugged======================================The game is definitely worth to get.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Ahh Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War, a game i just adore. I sunk countless hours into Dawn of War when i had the Disc copy of Dark Crusade. I've always been a fan of Warhammer 40,000 ever since i took my first trip into a GAMES WORKSHOP store when i was about 10. Playing the Table Top version currently, Warhammer is one of my favourite fictional universes. Dawn of War is a fantastic RTS game that has all the flair a 40K game should have. Having 9 playable Races as of the Soulstorm expansion; Space Marines, Eldar, Orcs, Chaos, Tau, Necrons, Imperial Guard, Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar, the game has a massive variety. It fearures the classic RTS style gameplay, base building and epic tonnes of units to destroy your foes with. Dawn of War II was such a dissapointment in my opinion as it didn't hold any of the key features the original had. The campaign is solid and has you travelling across the Kaurava system, eliminating any opposing armies in a grand game of Galactic Conquest. The Multiplayer is where it's at. Challenge friends, or test your luck online in skirmishes that can last between 15 minutes to 2 hours, each game being epic. If you haven't played Dawn of War (you've got something wrong with you) then pick it up, and experience one of the greatest RTS games ever made.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												I've played all the Dawn of War expansions and I think this is my favourite. There's two new races (Sisters of Battle and Derk Eldar), and all the exisiting races get an air unit. The use of a conquest campaign (like in Dark Crusade) also help the replayability! I did get the impression that the campaign wasn't as polished (not as many cutscenes) as Dark Crusade but it was still better, largely due to the additional races and more territories.I'm not a tabletop Warhammer fan, and Dawn of War: Dark Crusade was my first look into the 40k universe, so I don't know how well displayed the races are or anything like that, but as a RTS game this is brilliant. Dark Crusade was so good I went and got the Dawn of War and Dawn of War: Winter Assault on Steam. However, Dark Crusade was my favourite of the three, and Soulstorm is more in the Dark Crusade vein. You have to weigh up the advantages and disadvantages of your race and decide what your best tactic is for fighting each different race. So to a degree you have to keep changing up your tactic to suit the battle; I play as the Imperial Guard and my preferred tactic (from Dark Crusade's Annilation maps) is to dig in at first, build up my army and once I've tanks, artillery and infantry, push out and steamroll the enemy. In some maps, you need to take over 50% of the critical locations so I had to adapt my strategy.All in all, the new races are a fun addition. The air support also lends another depth to the game, while still keeping the Dark Crusade style intact. The conquest campaign with multiple planets also made the grand strategy more important to your conquest plan. I'd definitely reccommend this game, even if you already have Dark Crusade. Also, it's standalone, so even if you don't have any Dawn of War games you can still play it - so get it either way!!Also, check out moddb.com for the Strongholds mod, which lets you play all of the stronghold missions from Dark Crusade and Soulstorm as any race, against any race!

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												If you love the 40k universe, as I do, then you will love this game.This is basically a larger version of Dark Crusade, with very little changing to the playable races. There is the addition of flying units, though I have only found the Space Marine flyer to be of any real use, the others are pretty much a waste.  The two new races are the Sisters of Battle, whose tanks suck but have strong and relatively cheap infantry. I didn't think they have strong heavy weapons teams though. The other new race is the Dark Eldar, who are supposed to be fast, but individual units are weak and they don't seem to have a vehicle that get stompy Except for their Robo-Scorpion thing, which looks like it should belong to Chaos or Necrons, but it is a very solid smasher, and three of them will wreck most bases by themselves.I wish they would make more of these Dawn of War games rather than the small unit focused sequel.  I, for one, would like to see Chaos armies with specific Chaos God patronage...

												The black sheep of the Dawn of War 1 family, Soulstorm is admittedly a bit buggy, and has some of the weakest writing in the franchise. But we wouldn't still be making jokes about Indrick Boreale and his legendary baldness if it wasn't at least somewhat endearing. I can hardly blame Iron Lore for this game's shortcomings, as they were on their way out as it was. Go play Titan Quest or Grim Dawn if you want a real example of what that studio can do. What endeared Soulstorm to me as it is the only game I've played to date where the Sisters of Battle, one of the most underappricated factions in the setting by both players and creators, were not only present but playable. I played Soulstorm as much as I played Dark Crusade, and indeed any other Dawn of War title, and remember it as fondly.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Dawn of War:Soulstorm Is an amazing work of art that i have come to love over the course of my time playing the DoW seiries. This installment is the best one yet and is even better the the DoW2 seiries. The amount of time effort and care put into this game is just insane. Dont worry about your multiplayer expirence being ruined because the game is old, They changed their multiplayer system to run on the steam servers from gamespy so you can enjoy multiplayer as much as back in its Glory days. Dawn of war soulstorm has a high replay value despite the fact that the campaign may seem the same for all races. The way that the galaxy map is setup each playthrough will have different results. On one of my playthroughs as necrons i couldnt take the eldar stronghold, and after going to the Planet above me and capturing the IG's Stronghold the eldar somehow wiped me out (I still hate them to this day >:c). You can customize the colors of your army and Customize various strategies, as the population cap CANNOT hold 1 squad of each unit, making strategy a must. Although population caps are low, The implementation of squads in the game make it so their are actually LOTS of units on the screen but also makes them much more manageable, And if you have a good PC and are a bit more bloodthirsty you can use mods to raise the population limit in singleplayer AND Multiplayer, or get new race/new unit mods, Or even get Full conversion mods. (My favorite mod being Ultimate Apocalypse).Overall Dawn of War: Soulstorm is an excellent game and well wroth the price, If its a multiplayer expierence your after however, I recommend waiting for a sale and buying all the original Dawn of wars as it will unlock all the races for you in multiplayer and the other installments are well worth it as well.Story: 9.8/10Gameplay: 8.6/10Multiplayer: 9.2/10Audio: 8.2/10Visual: 7.6/10Final Score: 9.4/10

Buy this game 2. download the ultimate apocolypse mod (http://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-mod/downloads/ultimate-apocalypse-patch-1739) and the tyranid mod (http://www.moddb.com/mods/tyranid-mod/downloads/tyranid-mod-v05b2-for-soulstorm) and run the installer (make sure it installs into your steam dawn of war soulstorm file)3. start the game, go to game manager, activate "Ultimate Apocalypse with Tyranids"4. play each race against the AI until you find the race you like the most5. buy the expansion that includes that race (if its tyranids, sisters of battle, or dark eldar you already have them from this game)6. recruit friends to follow step 1-57. start up online games with friends8. enjoy your WHAAAGH! content:
Posted: January 22
												A must have for any RTS player who likes building army's with basebuilding, this time u can even paint and logo your own army and banners.The resource collection and economy works different, u capture 3 diffrent type of points, most are requisition points, one power and one relic is all u need. most armys will get lets say their main income from requisition points except the necrons as far as i know, for them, power is the main income.power works different as well, it also works as income, so the more u build or the more power points u take the more income of '' power '' u get.u spend requisition and power on buildings and units / expanding units and on upgrades.and the last one, relic points are one for each player in the map, capturing this will grand access to lets say the superweapon unit and the elite units of your army.all points can be defended by building outpost on them and upgrading them, except power points, u need to build around them to defend them.so that is basicly how it works and its more easy then it sounds really.there are tons of races, units and buildings and tons of upgrades, when u think u are done and upgrade your main, everything has upgrades again.painting your own army and giving them logo's and creating your own banner is also unique to dawn of war.every race plays different in building and in army.all the expansions and the original have great campaings two of them have a risk like campaign map with some ingame cinematics.9/10 cant wait for dawn of war 3 wich will come out this year.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												As someone who is no stranger to the RTS genre, I'll admit, this one threw me for a loop at first!The most interesting thing here is the campaign.  Typically, your average RTS is either a survival game where you build up forces to withstand assault or it's a level-by-level progression, where you complete sequential missions.  This was the first time I actually felt like I was playing both at once.  The campaign mode of this game is odd, but in a good way; it's a refreshing way to bridge the two different styles of RTS into a unique gameplay system.Another interesting mechanic is the different races in the game.  Usually, different races will have a general build order that all follow the same way, or there are a few radically different races.  With this game, each race has a unique build style to explore!  The Imperial Guard have garrisonable buildings, the Eldar can Teleport, the Battle Sisters have Holy Relics... it's like each race is it's own unique game!(P.S.: If you're a bigtime RTS player like I am, and you're just now getting into this game, then I recommend starting as the Tau when you first play this game; their build order is more familiar to folks coming from a Starcraft or CiV background.)The only downside to this "expansion"/game, I would say, is the lack of a story.  I mean, there is one, but it's very underplayed in this expansion.  It takes a bit of RP to really get into the story; not like Winter Assault or Dark Crusade, where there's a very obvious storyline to follow.  Still, this isn't really a big issue with the game itself; if you're already a big 40K fan, then you might not even notice it at all.All in all, a wonderful spin on the RTS games.  9/10.  Looking to get the other DoW1 titles, to experience the other stories in this game series.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												There are a few issues that need to be highlighted regarding Soulstorm before I begin listing the positive aspects of this game. First off, the game has a lot of issues with loading, particularly with the campaign. Though I'll readily admit that my computer isn't a good one, the general concensus is that no game should keep you waiting as long as the Soulstorm Campaign does, so have a book or handheld system by your side if you intend to play the campaign. Secondly, as I'm sure a good chunk of you know, most of the voice acting for the Campaign mode is absolutely terrible, but this isn't a major issue as much as it is a gripe (most of the issues regarding the game come from the campaign).Now, on to the postives.This expansion adds two new factions to play as, the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar, both of which are welcome additions to the game. Both bring new strategies to the table, as well as giving you a better look at the 40k universe (I say this because Dawn of War is most people's gateway to Warhammer 40,000). The gameplay is still solid (though of course balance is still a major issue), because few expansion packs can really mess up gameplay.And last but not least, the real reason you should purchase this game: The mods.There are dozens of amazing mods for Soulstorm, from ambitious gameplay overhauls like Titanium Wars and Ultimate Apocalypse, to new factions (complete with voice acting) like the Armageddon Steel Legion and Tyranids. If you're not sure about getting Soulstorm, do it for the mods.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Overall I really like this game, however if there is one thing I do have a problem with it is the balance. some factions (races, whatever) are stronger than others, or at least have a extremly powerful and cheap way to win. There are also some which are weaker than adverage and are always lurking when you decide to random. To show my point better i will show for each faction a cheap or unbalanced tactic (or if a faction does not have one, the best you can do) This is mainly from tactics I or my friends have used that we all agree are pretty broken. (list is in random order)Chaos: get 2 to 3 raptor squads early game, this is both very effective at rush defence (or a rush) but it is also particuarly effective against factions the rely heavily on ranged unitsOrks: get 2 or 3 slugga boyz right away and max them out as much as you can (do not wait to build a waagh tower) then rush. You however can and should build a waagh tower while you rush to give you more squad members.  Almost gauranteed to work except against chaos or if they have prepared for the rush.Necrons: Making an entire army out of flayed ones. They will almost instantly break the enemy's morale and they also do some insane melee damage. (be careful though they are slow and easily outmicroed)Eldar: Just don't play them, they are the worst race in the game.Sisters of Battle: they are ok, me and my friends have not found an op tactic for them though.  just build a lot of battle sister squads early game and don't build seraphim squads (not enough damage to effectivly harass)Imperial guard: They do not really have and overpowered tactic however if you don't want to die make sure you can defend against large amounts of melee units as they suck in melee. Also understand that they are very expendable.Dark Eldar: A gigantic improvement over the normal Eldar, they have an extremely powerful melee vehicle called the Talos, this thing will destroy infantry and unless they have anti tank is a very big threat.Space marines: for the most part not overpowered, however I did see a pretty broken tactic once. my friend rushed to dreadnaugnts and sent and attack. that was not the problem though. He had researched an ability that allowed him to drop down troops in a drop pod. he kept sending dreadnaught after dreadnaught and my army was not able to kill them in time before he sent in another one (he was also sending in terminator squads) I had 3 to 4 full squads of imperial guard with grenade launchers firing at them and workers repairing my buildings but I eventually lost to sheer spam.Tau: get 1 to 2 kroot and them spam fire warriors in the back. Having done this myself I watched as entire squads were obliterated in seconds. However the one thing that does hinder you is that their units are very expensive and require good map control to get the resources to really get the ball rolling.As you can see there are balance issues but it is still a fun game to play with some friends.If this review was comepletly terrible keep in mind it is my first one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Dawn of War Soulstorm is the final piece of the Dawn of War 1 "series." It added 2 factions (Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle) and 1 new unit for each race. The comparisons to Dark Crusade are inevitable so let's compare and contrast. Dark Crusade's persistant bases give you a reason to prolong a match so as to build up a good base for the next fight. Unfortunately, it also means that defenses can be insurmountable creating a World War 1 like stalemate. This was done away with in Soulstorm which created much shorter more offensive gameplay. Other complaints I have heard is in regards to the voice acting as opposed to Dark Crusade. Well, actually, this is true. There is significantly reduced dialogue in this one compared to Dark Crusade. Which is a genuine shame considering how much I enjoyed the back-and-forth of the two commanders as I assaulted a stronghold.Would I recommend it though? Short answer. Yes, just look at my time played. Of course this game is worth the money, and then some. If you need a great RTS or love Warhammer 40K, grab this game. Just do it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Now, I know that a lot of (actual tabletop) 40k fans will really be upset at the initial aspect of this games and most of the series, and, yes i know im writing a review like-years, after the game has come out-bear with me...anyways, i love the 40k universe, and anyone who does as well, should think about investing in the DOW series, (even DOW II followups), however, for tabletop 40k fans, especially those like myself, who REALLY love the lore, the armies, and don't just cater to the standard Ultramarine (sorry, I meant untrasmurf) stereotype, but actually play other not (as) popular armies, such as the dark angels (yes, yes i know there still spehss marines, and yes i KNOW tons of you who know about tabletop will say, but Belial, DAs are a popular army-to you guys i say-wrong!!! they may be in "the common" crowd more than some other armies like sisters, but they still have their own niche) anyways, back on topic-as vanilla standards go, campaign wise, it is somewhat realistic to 4th edition (and i use somewhat, loosely) however, if you truly, (and i mean truly,) want to see the different armies and factions shine in their own roles, or affinities, i suggest, first off, play through the campaign with your favorite faction, get used to how the game works (for those unfamilliar with rts, which i doubt any of you purchasing this game are) then proceed to download mods, the most popular (and probably controversial for those without an understanding of 40k) i suggest the Ultimate Apocalypse Mod, for more specific mods, i suggest codex mods (although, according to some of my testing, most codex mods dont go through, i think maybe 5th edition codex'?) so your probably better off with ultimate apocalypse, just be sure to watch tutorials, and READ EVERYTHING, if your new to the modding sceneAnyways, as for the game itself, it is a lot different for those who have played let's say dark crusade, as the campagin is a little differnt in how it works, (although in my opinion, much more realistic to 40k lore) for newcomers (sp) to rts titles, get ready to learn how to micromanage the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everything, as what (special) weapons or wargear you research/ equip can either greatly hinder or benefit you, one tip, KNOW YOUR ENEMY, for those without an understanding of the different races and the strengths and weaknesses, or what they can field, look up info about them on the web (seriously) as even the vanilla game (sorta) keeps to 40ks "rules"As a wrap up, this game is great, for either dedicated 40k fans, or rts lovers, or even for someone looking to get into the rts scene, just, if you want the "whole" story (at least for the early DOW titles) buy the games when their packaged on steam, (i got these games when they first came out for pc on disk, and still have the disks, {dont even think about calling me old, all you 12 year olds} however with the times, i have needed to purchase the re-released digital copies to effectively run multiplayer etc. as the main servers which ran them, {i believe at least} are no longer supported due to internal company strife, etc.)Anyways, i hope this has been helpful for those on the fence, or are trying to get into 40k DOW, friend or message me if you want more info (no im not trying to bait people for friends, thats why i gave the option to just message-uh, duh) AS Always, serve the emperor with pride, purge the xenos, and Deus Ex Destiny!++The Sword in Silence++

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												One of my favorite RTS of all time. Played Dark Crusade over years and Soulstorm is as good. But you have to like the 2 new races.The balance is a bit off hand compared to StarCraft. But the matches are fast and intense and much fun and bring the sweat to your forehead. The Animations like the little finishing moves for every unit are great to the present day and blew my mind back in 2004. So the battles are bloody and ruthless as it should be for 40k game. All in all: Relic did a great job in conveying the universe into a RTS game. Also are the online matches fast and intense and the 9 diffrent races bring a great variety and lots of strategies to experiment with. Sadly the balance is a bit off in online battles.Strongly recommended if you like RTS.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Soulstorm is the final and in my opinion, best expansion for the critically acclaimed Dawn Of War I franchise that got unfortunately hounded by reviewers at launch, but was greatly enhanced by both official patches and mods that made this game one of the most famous and game-changing RTS's out there.+ Standalone expansion that adds the fanatical sisters of battle, with a a wide array of artillery and faith based attacks, and the sadistic, twisted dark eldar, who are nothing like the original Eldar faction and are the epitome of the term glass cannon with the highest damage in the game, but also the worst health I've ever seen.+ Balanced older factions making it a better experience for all+ Those that own Soulstorm do not need any other part of DOW I to play with others who own the franchise (assuming they too own atleast Soulstorm) but you are restricted from the factions added in other expansions giving you access to only 2 of the 9+ The meta-campaign returns giving you the ability to fight in the 9-way war for Kaurava.+ Airforce based units are added making fighter jets available to all (except the Necron, but they get a spell that hijacks vehicles permenantly now) adding a new level of diversity to the combat as they dont follow the same movement restrictions as ground troops.+The game can be further enhanced with the legendary Ultimate Apocalypse mod adding new balance changes, better graphics, units, and redoes every faction from the ground up making them as the Codex Astartes (basically lore for the universe for the  heretics  those unfamiliar with the lore reading this ) states making it one of the greatest mods for any game ever. That is a fact, opinions do not matter in the 40th millenia.- The ai is still kinda wonky on lower difficulties and will not always utilize their best features on higher ones. For example, the Eldar, who are meant to be a teleportation based army with weak hit-and-run style units, will instead opt for buildig multiple unupgraded guardian (rifleman) squads and rush you by the two minute mark. This works well if you didnt build a turret which mows them down violently, but it still doesn't fit with how that faction was meant to work. This can be fixed with mods however.-Due to age, and a community divided over mods, finding people to play with isn't always easy. If you have friends into RTS games however, this game is a god(emperor)send.-The new aerial units take a lot of damage from even basic infantry making them not very viable in many instances. So if your looking for some high end combined arms assault, all your gonna get is some quality infantry and armored vehicles fighting as dead pilots drop down.-The controversial commander units are back, though not as dangerous as they are in the second game as they are still very much killable by even the weaker units. In my opinion, they aren't too much of an issue and as a concept add to the game, though balance is a tad bit skewed as some armies get their primary and best commanders at the beginning like the Space/Chaos marines and dark eldar when others have to wait for a base upgrade or other enhancement. I feel that these guys have a bit too much early game infantry harassment but by the end is no issue.-A full-fleged story based campaign is still absent like in Dark Crusade but the new campaign format included in the two allows you to play as your favorite faction instead of either the Space marines in the base game, or 1-2 missions for each in the Winter Assault. In conclusion, the game still holds up and is still fantastic to play in both standard and the Ultimate Apocalypse mod. Balance still isn't perfect, but the more you play you should be able to master and hold up as any faction making it one of the most biggest and greatest RTS games out there.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												EDIT: Seeing as Sega is now involved with this game and has started up the DoW servers once again making online play much easier over Steam, this game is worth all the more. GET IT!!Yes.Yes, yes, yes.Note that the Steam game time does not give my actual game time credit. I had this game way before I had Steam, and I've probably spent 250+ hours on it.For all you RTS junkies, THQ, Relic and Games Workshop created this. This is by far the best RTS game i've ever played (mostly gameplay wise). The story might not be as thrilling or entertaining as other RTS games, but who plays RTS games for the cutscenes?Dawn of War (all of them, but Soulstorm is more worth getting as it has all the races) is definitely the best RTS game i've played, bringing in new aspects of gaining resources and building armies that are absolutely great. Maps are awesome and designed very well, and the units and special abilities will satisfy you greatly. Dawn of War's races can vary very much, with some races such as the Necrons or Dark Eldar having special aspects that are completely alien compared to the other 7 races, so it has a good choice of the style of play that will keep you entertained for hours. After playing this game for long enough, you'll find yourself quoting the phrases the units say all the time - by far the best being "WIIIIITNEEEESSS EEYOUR DOOOOOOOMMMMMEE!!!"Very good game, must buy!

Posted: December 20, 2013
												While perhaps not as highly regarded as Dark Crusade by some, DOW: Soulstorm creates an enjoyable RTS experence.  Each of the races has a different feel and lends itself to different types of strategy and yet each race also has the ability to overcome its weaknesses.  This extension of DOW adds flying units (except Nekrons) and two new races, of which I have found the Sisters of Battle particuarly fun tio play.  The flying units are nice but not a real powerhouse of the game.  On the downside, the map is a tad less dynamic than DC--I feel its predecessor had more options in its pathing, but the races balance better in Soulstorm.  The difficulty levels also offer greatly different game experiences.  The campaign is nice for an extended play, especially if you change races it can be like a new game.  The skirmish mode also allows for some quick, fun play.  The AI is ok--you might find yourself able to begin overunning the map in campaign mode once you have won a few victories in a row at times.  Overall, I recommend this game for its replayability and various levels of alien color.

I'll admit that I prefer Dark Crusader over this as the addition of flying units didn't work very well and the writers kinda messed up on the campaign, but the modding community is actually pretty good!  The Titanium Wars mod actually takes away the flyers and adds a lot of new units making the game very difficult and refreshed the entire campaign as the new units really bring a new experience. 												Excellent game.Played it a lot many years ago. I played it competitve in 1on1, clan wars and esl and just for fun. What I like the most is that you have to focus on many things, eco management, base building and teching, tactics and unit micromanagement. The combat system with ranged and melee, knockback and stunning is very good as well.Plus you have 9 factions wich play very unique and are still perfectly balanced.I wished relic would have all these good things in COH2 as well.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												   I've been playing this game for ages, longer than I've had Steam, and I still come back to it nearly every week. Obviously, this game isn't nearly as interesting for people who don't know the 40k universe as it is to fans of it, but it is still a very enjoyable game with lots of replayability, and is a solid game with or without the 40k setting.    The replayability only really comes from the skirmish and multiplayer, as I find the campaign to be a bit repetitive and quite franky not very interesting. Plus, while there is a good selection of units in this installment in the series, I always find the there is always a couple of units for every race that I seldom use unless I specifically work them into my strategy. My only other real complaint is that there is sometimes annoying pathing issues with units moving in a large group, and if you are playing with AI it can become quite tedious.    Other than that, i absolutely love these games, mainly due to the awesome unit models and animations etc. The army painter is also a really nice feature that allows you to create your own armies or recreate known ones from the 40k universe (to some degree - it is a bit simple for some designs). The aesthetic and overall art style ties in very well with the setting aswell, including all the viscera and crater holes that are left behind from bloody combat. The maps are also varied and are good sizes for the most part. The game itself also makes you feel like your part of the battle, and the strategic point based gameplay is a nice spin on traditional RTS.   Overall, it's a solid game with some fun features, but it is the setting and the aesthetic that keeps me playing, probably because I am a big fan of the 40k universe. So to conclude, if you are into 40k, it is a very worthwhile purchase, but if you aren't... eh, I'd still buy the game.

Posted: July 26, 2013
												When a young man is told that "A moment of laxity spawns a lifetime of heresy" he is not the same ever again. It happened to me as well, and Warhammer 40 000 is still my favorite "commercial" fantasy world. It seems unreal yet plausible, like a funny nightmare perhaps. Relic has captured the spirit of 40K perfectly, and the games are great on their own as well. This is the fourth and final part of Dawn of War 1, and Relic gave the design duties to Iron Lore. It shows, for the campaign is an inferior repetition of Dark Crusade, and the writing is generic at best. Yet the original gameplay is beyond all criticism, and the two new armies are realized very well. There are a total of nine factions, and all are worth attention and playtime. Iron Lore folded and Soulstorm patch cycle stopped. There is a Maktaka Bugfix Mod, which is absolutely essential. It should work with Steam as well.

												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn Of War - Soulstorm is a great game for laughs, especially if you are a 40k fanboy. It's also a great game for killing Xenos and burning heretics. The gameplay is very fun with swarms of Space Marines charging into other waste lands. It has hours of unlimited fun but it does get a bit boring after playing 6 hours a day. Soulstorm is a gigantic mod with lots of maps. I recommend it for you fanboys who hate orks XD8/10Chop2015

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												In the Grim Darkness of the future there is only War. Soulstorm is an excellent expansion of the series, Dawn of War. I highly recomend the series, as it can lead to addicting hours of play, alone or with friends. It is friendly with many computers of all ages, and there are good mods that can extend how much you play this game. (Ultimate Apocolypse is my favorite mod, as it is more fluff friendly.) Recomended for those new to the universe and those who are veterans in the galaxy of war. Fight in His Glorious name, the God-Emperor of Mankind, or for the Ruinious Powers of Chaos, or even perhaps in the name of the Xenos who fight for their own ends. You decide, and you shall carve into history.     The story of the series is wonderful in itself, although not as grand or as well told as the first or Winter Assault. Dark Crusade and Soulstorm non the less allow for a fun twist of domination for the sector. They tie in slightly with the Dawn of War II series, but are not necasary for DoW II. (Note: Multiplayer comes with its own race from each game. GotY/Gold gives Space Marines, Orks, Eldar and Chaos. Winter Assault grants the Imperial Guard. Dark Crusade allows for Tau and Necrons. Soulstorm itself grants the zealotous, the Sisters of Battle, and the dreaded Dark Eldar. Alone in Skirmish *should* allow you to play as any race, however.)

content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												Yes there are cons about this. You do have to buy all 4 games to get all of the races, and I get it, that is annoying. However, the modding community for this game is great, and there is one in particular that I would like to talk about. Ultimate Apcolypse mod is a fan made mod that adds the Tryanids, better game settings, (it also has a map pack that increases the zoom distance and increases visibility when you zoom out) it is still getting updated, recently there had been 2 more custom races added: The Inquisition with the totally badass Grey Knights (know as Daemonhunters in game), and Chaos Daemons, not to forget the improvements on all other races with new units and textures/models. The creators of the mod are great at what they've done and I think that they are one of the main reasons why I love Warhammer so much, so props to them. If you want the mod, here is a link to their download page (virus free btw):http://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-mod/downloadsPlease note that the game still has desync and desync errors, and it requires a more resources to not have lag. (however if you have it set so that you have massive battles with a population cap over 100, you will probably get at bit of lag, especially since the mod is basically a massive overhaul of the original. The mod itself is more than 10GB, but it is really worth it, trust me.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is a game that has been in my library for a long time and always remains installed.  The games are quick and it has such tremendous replay value with all of the different races stacked in from the other games.  Resources are simple as well.  If you like to dive into the action instead of sending peons off to gather stuff then this is the game for you!  It's easier to maintain fights a long way from your base as well because each squad replenishes their units directly instead of having to wait for reinforcements to trudge all the way across the map.  To top it off, the Army Painter is great fun and lets you really customize and save the look of different armies.  I definitely recommend this game.

Posted: April 24
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												As it has all of the factions, this should be considered the strongest of the Dawn of War 1 installments. Its great for both fans of 40k or for newcomers (or those too poor to buy far too expensive sets)While some of the fighting gets tedious, there are few other flaws wih Dawn of War: Soulstorm. Its great for creating your own story in the Warhammer 40,000 universe. Are you a dishourned space marine captain fighting to regain his peers respect? A vengeful Eldar leader hoping to avenge their kin? Or a human traitor who only wishes for the dark gods to rule the universe? All of these and more are available.+Great storytelling from your own perspective.+Nice customisation options+Some interesting and rare factions like Sisters of Battle+Excellent battles during the middle of a battle+Nice, interesting battle play style+You can turn a chaos general into Satan+Half of the factions seem to be drug addicts (Chaos, Eldar, Dark Eldar)/Outdated graphics, good for the original-No tyranids (still)-Tedious gameplay towards the endScore: 7/10 - Good

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												(Reviews of mine posted on the expansions are the exact same as this one)Enjoy playing a game that stands tall and proud even now. Enjoy playing a game that has virtually no balance problems. Enjoy playing a game with 9 different races that somehow all play the same, something that Starcraft 2 Heart of The Swarm currently is beginning to fail at.Enjoy playing a game where each race has a super weapon that is literally a giant unit from a giant tank, to a large, fat pyramid-ish cube with a giant laser beam, or even a big pig...thing with lasers on it's head, bigger than the swimming pool you went to last month.Trust me... these Super Weapons put Command and Conquer's Super Weapons at the kiddie table, they make them look like pea shooters almost. Oh... what's that? One is an energy field that makes all tanks and vehicles invulnerable for a short time? One of them is an ion blast fired from a sattelite in space or something? One of them is a nuke?Only the Nuke super weapon stands up to any of these.The game works off of unlimited resources known as Requisition and Power. Power, you make generators to make, and Requisition is gained from taking and holding points throughout a map. Both can be upgraded in a different way to produce more resources faster.Anyonewho is a fan of strategy games who has NOT played this one is just simply missing out.This game is the closest anyone will ever get to a seemingly perfect game in it's own rights, and to add to it, it's got wonderful voiceacting, awesome soundtracks and rather impressive visuals for it's time, all of which stands just aswell today.Hardcore RTS fans can agree that if you are a HUGE fan of the Real-Time Strategy Game, you owe it to yourself to try this.The game has 3 expansions, the first one adds The Imperial Gaurd, the second adds the Tau and Necrons, and the thirds adds the Sisters of Battle and the Dark Eldar.All 3 add onto the game and simply make it one of the best if not the best RTS in existence so far.Also only Soulstorm has much of an actual multiplayer, because people only play it, so if multiplayer is what you're looking for... well try out the skirmish mode, and if you like this, get the 3 expansions and join us in the crusade to kill eachother!This game is easily an 8/10, it's simply gaming bliss.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I put hundreds of hours into this game before I had it on steam.  It is one of the best RTS games out there.  The other expansions and base game are good too, but this is the last of them so it includes the most.  Play as the Space Marines, Chaos Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Sisters of Battle, Tau, Eldar, Necrons, Orks, or Dark Eldar.  Build a massive army, capture points, and take on the enemy in PVP, the campaign, or skirmish mode against bots.  Really an amazing game.  I would like to recommend another game within this review that is not on Steam.  The Battle For Middle Earth II, along with it's expansion The Rise of the Witch-King.  Really excellent games.
