content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Before reading the fact I recommend the game, keep in mind that the game is better with mods which is what really makes it worth buying and replaying. Overall hours played if I count the time before I finally decided to re-purchase it via Steam is about 1.5k hours as this was the most played strategy game in my collection back in the day.Vanilla Review:Dawn of War Soulstorm has many, many unfinished abilities and units which take away from the overall effect of multiplayer and campaign abilities. While in itself it is still a good title and a replayable campaign for AI grinding is still fun, if Relic/THQ had actually finished their project, it would of been a lot better.The Campaign is basically a repeat of Dark Crusade but you got Tau and Sisters of Battle now which isn't really that much. Overall balancing is okay but there is a lot left to be desired such as knockback spam being hard to counter or defend against and special weapons troopers always being the first to die even if they're in the back of the squad being attacked.The vanilla version also does a very poor job at vehicle implementation particularly with aircraft as they're glorified glass cannons in some cases (Orks) and useless in almsot all accords (Imperial Guard).  Limiting special units in most cases where in Dark Crusade you could have more is a double edged sword and the limits should of been raised. Having the ability to only create one elite troop unit compared to three back in Dark Crusade is a major debuff in my opinion and overall takes away from the fighting experience as most of them are very weak to begin with.The developers have also neglected balancing between every race. Races such as the Orks and Tau are extremely powerful against most other factions and in some cases you can't even win if it's against a competent player or the AI on the highest difficulty such as Orks vs Imperial Guard....you can't even win in a balanced fight particularly if it's 3v3 or 4v4 due to the Invulnerability spam on Ork units. Now if you do Orks vs Space Marines or even Eldar, it's a lot easier because the races aren't glass cannons. Imperial Guard it seems has been mostly balanced from a 1v1 stand point and team fight with non-Imperial Guard races which is a shame because they should be able to do well in team fights with other Guard players but in almost every instance, that is not the case. Sisters of Battle are extremely strong in all stages of the game and honestly minus the fact they're basically infantry only, can beat almost every faction in a 1v2 instance. Tau are glorified glass cannons and with the length of their tech tree, most games end before you can even begin to put the hurt on the enemy in a 1v1. Their entire tech tree is based off long team fights where they really shine and often end up losing in early game fights on small maps due to their higher maintenance costs and the lack of defenses. Eldar/Dark Eldar and SM/CSM have changed very little and are good at all stages, no reall balancing needed. Necrons, very very good late stages but absolutely get massacured early game in even fights. Not even balanced in a 1v1 perspective or even 2v2, they show the least amount of balancing from the developers and honestly only shine on large maps where you can't get rushed at one minute into the game.Overall Score: 7/10Campaign 5/10Multiplayer 8/10Game Mechanics 8/10Replay Value 10/10Balacning 6/10Ultimate Apocalypse Review:This is the way the game should be played IF your computer is capable of supporting it. It expands upon the vanilla build and releases several more functions that make the game more enjoyable in addition to implementing several functions that were left unfinished such as additional units and abilities.The mod also implements the Tyranids and Inquisition (WIP) for play in addition to a few new maps but overall is a massive rebalancing project that is catered as well towards Super Heavy battles. Trust me, if you want a tank war, this is the mod for you especially if you play Imperial Guard. It embraces the doctrine of "We have a tank for that too!"The ability for all races to now build defensive turrets and in some cases walls/barricades is an added bonus on smaller maps to help prevent rushing and the ability to further upgrade defensive buildings and resources helps solve the problem of resource stagnation in most games making it much easier to continue playing late game even if you end up losing your armies rapidly.The mod also rebalances aircraft which in the Vanilla version were a joke and a waste of resources. In addition to the mod expanding both the capabilities of each race, it also drastically increases the scale of destruction and carnage you can witness. The mod is still a WIP which is good because it is constantly rebalanced and a few new races are being implemented.Ultimate Apoclaypse Link: http://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-modOverall Score 9/10Balancing 8/10Game Mechanics 10/10Campaign 10/10Replay Value 10/10Multiplayer 9/10

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												It has Force Commander Boreale, 40,000/10!!!!Alright This game has many merits to stand on beyond an Astartes Commander with a speech problem.The game uses Dark Crusade's formula of Risk-ish province attack, defense and Commander upgrades for the space between skirmish battles, with more important Faction Strongholds and bonus missions being spread about the map. The difference? Instead of just being a landmass, the battle map is an ENTIRE DAMN SOLAR SYSTEM.The Expansion also adds two new Factions. Namely the Dark Eldar (Fallen Eldar slavers) and the SIsters of battles (Space Nuns with power armour). Both of these new factions have their quirks, with the Dark Eldar gaining a reasource for their special abilites from haresting their foes Corpses, and the Sisters Gaining both power and faith the more of a specific building you have.However, removeing those new races the expansion is basicly the same as dark crusade but with two new races and over many planets instead of just one. The game only has one other merit of note. That being the new unit's Voice workIT IS SO BAD AND I LOVE IT. As i mentioned at the start of this review, the Space Marine Boreale's voice actor has a bit of an accent with makes his speech so damn funny (Bhatal Bruvas, Spess Marhens, Steal Rein!). The game also spawned Chaos Lord Carron, as-well his meme worthy response to the space marines use of Rhino armoured transports, below is a transcript."Look! RHINOS *Inhale* RHINOS! OUR ENEMYS HIDE IN METAL BOXES THE COWARDS, THE FOOLS!!! *Deep inhale* We shall take away their metal boxes!"7.5/10

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Dawn of War® - Soulstorm is a game I love, hate, and love to hate - I just can't make heads or tails of it. The gameplay is both really good and really terrible.What makes it good is the diversity available - this is the first strategy game I've ever played that has a staggering count of NINE playable races, but what counters that is that they're all extremely complex and hard to understand. The actual gameplay of resource points and what not, though, is kind of puzzling, and I would have honestly preferred to just stay with the traditional resource gathering. In many ways, it sort of reminds me of Tiberian Twilight; the less said about that game the better.So since Steam forces me with a "black or white" option with "yes or no", I'll recommend this game with a "yes", though it's probably not for everybody.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												I love Warhammer 40,000 Dawn Of War.This game is Superior to many RTS games even in todays standards and never fails to provide edge of the seat action and battles that keep you entertained time and again. It is very content rich and has very worthwhile DLC and is a steal in the sale which it has a very low price.Dawn Of War is a base building RTS that offers many building and tech options to unlock more units and better upgrades or better defences. You also have to manage various resources such as energy to build these things which can be very hard.I found the story to be very lackluster and i would expect and want more from this. It is basically an excuse for the races to fight eachother for no reason. It is played in a risk based grid in a sector but does have meaningful deecisions such as where to defend or put various armies.The Good:There are nine different races with each having a way of playing and have different units tactics and tech to choose from. This increases replayability and makes sure there is a race for everyone.A wide variety of customization from colors and loooks and the army name making each army unique to the player and gives personality.A wide variety of units building tactics and tech for each faction.Multiplayer still has a large communit and singleplayer skirmish can be a challenge with over 100 maps with various terrian.The Bad:Story SUCKSCannot personalize what they can wear.AI can be studip at times but is generally good.It was very hard to find fault with the game as it is just that good and i advise you get the game NOW!!!!

												This used to be a great game, until Sega got a hold of it and ruined it. I'd happily recommend this game if the LAN option was once again added. The only thing that removing the LAN option does is encourage people to pirate versions of the game prior to the THQ collapse.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30
												If I could give neutral reviews this game would probably get one. Good- Honor Guards - Unlock wargear - Two new races Bad- Maps no longer save: If you had to defend a province in 'Dark Crusade' you would start exactly where you had left off, with all the buildings you built and all the listening posts you had claimed. Now a "defense mission" is the same as playing a skirmish map. - No spaceport: Conquering the spaceport in 'Dark Crusade' allowed you to attack anywhere on the map and pick up what bonus/honor guard you wanted to go for first. Now you'll have to use "old portals" which takes much longer to move around and also allows the enemy to attack your province, forcing you to play another "skirmish map"[TL;DR]If you're looking for an expansion pack, go for 'Dark Crusade' first and pick up 'Soulstorm' when it's on a sale. This game certainly doesn't deserve all the hate it gets, but it feels like a downgrade after DC.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												In DC, a level 2 area consisted of a single base, barracks only, and a few enemy squads with no additional troops. In this version, a lvl 2 area is three tier 3 enemy bases, a never ending stream of dreadnaughts, constant attacks from 4+ squads of fully geared infantry and relic summons every time you fend off an attack. It's so difficult it's not enjoyable anymore. I wish the difficulty  was balanced like it is in DC.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												I would really like to recommend this game, it is by far the  best Dawn of War game. Sadly, my experience would suggest otherwise. I cannot beat the campaign simply because after each main base or settlement (whatever you want to call it) crashes infinitely. Meaning, that I cannot truly beat the game, even if I desired so.  This call was on a 50/50, for the negative recommendation, as the base game (along with  a mod that fixed the camera height)  IS my favorite Dawn of War game.This game feels dated as far as some of the mechanics and graphics go. It is all forgiven with the simply yet complex styled gameplay that only the original Dawn of War series could bring.TL:DR Game breaking bug prevents from experiencing all Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War® - Soulstorm has to offer. Despite these bugs, it is a good game.

												as a big fan of warhammer dawn of war i wanted to try soulstorm after buying dark crusade on amazon, comparing the two i was bitterly dissapointed with soulstorm, the only new units it adds to the dark crusade armies were unimpressive aircraft units which to be frank were more like skimmers that could jump over impassable terrain, i wasnt impressed with the two new factions either, to be fair i only tried the sisters of battle which seemed a bit unorthadox to the authenticity of the 4Ok universe, alongside this there was no difference to any other data when it came to existing units there were the same unit pictures and descriptions, to further show the indefferences from the two games the leaders of each existing factions where not much different to there predeccesors infact they were more ripoffs if youd like, in conclusion dont make the mistajke i made when you get complacent with dark crusade ~amazing game by the way~ and think that soulstorm would refresh your dawn of war experiance.. it doesnt,

content:
Posted: May 31, 2011
												Thank god they finally got around to adding some boobs to the Space Marines. This franchise was one giant testosterone injection (Eldar exempted, of course) and the addition of some females makes the experience as a whole much, much better. And by better I mean breasts. It's not just mammaries, though: this standalone expansion also adds a new, very bad campaign, as if to send the message that women ruin everything. Gazongas + misogynism isn't really a groundbreaking theme in video games, but it's an underrepresented one in the RTS genre, so Soulstorm really fills a void that has really only been addressed by the Red Alert series. I award this game 5 out of 5 funbags!

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Definately an awesome stratagy game. The lack of micro managing 'villagers/workers' to harvest resources keep you focused on the fight more often, and your resources are based off capturing specific locations scattered on the map. The fundamentals : squad based units, access to iconic units and vehicles, nice visuals, and an interesting take on unit upgrades. If you enjoy this game you'll like Dawn of war Dark crusade aswell, being nearly identical only lacking the dark eldar race and the Sisters of battle. No big loss really...You might also check out the Titanium wars mod, for both soulstorm and dark crusade.For a warhammer fan or an RTS fan, a must buy.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Do i recommend this game? yes and no..This is not so much a game as it is a slapped together map pack, the story consists of a voice over saying a warp opened up and tada every one arrived.. that's itAll with weak reasoning, he turned up so he decided to, the other thought well if they're here.. you get every thing of the get go, no progression just there ya go, kill em.. the strategic points are generic with almost no thought to placement almost symetrically lined up across the boardthe fact that youer enemy is called computer- enemy -team 1 says it all, soul storm? souless more like..the redeeming factor (the reason i bought the game)  was the map progession fight back and forth on world maps controlling countries loosing countries that's about it... i expected an awesome tug of war with nicely built maps and clever cut scenes to set the mood, but ya get nuthinif you and friends want to play (can you still do that?) then i guess it's okay...maybe they knew that THQ was going down and had to complete the war hammer series in one foul swoop..either way meh, i don't know what ppl think is so good about it, sorta sucks.6/10

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												[/h1]" For the Greater Good "[/h1]So, This my very first detailed review about DoW SS. The game was developed in 2008 by Iron Lore Entertainment andRelic Entertainment  and published by THQ.The game is an RTS which takes place in the universe of Warhammer 40k which is one of the most popular franchise of the Games Workshop. The game is a standalone expansion of Dawn of War (2004) After getting trhough the generals let's jump to the review itself[/h1] " We are the Emperors chosens" (first impressions)[/h1]So first of all the gameplay itself is a bit different that we have already get used to. We will ned to make a base for sure but we won't need to collect any resources. Instead we have to capture points (similar to Company of Heroes) and build generators. The first gives us the base recourse and the least gives us energy endeed. There are 9 playable races (!!! only 2 in multi if you don't have the previous 3 DoWs !!!) but I will talk about the later.The game itself is multiplayer oriented and have a very good community. People still making mods and play online with the game after 6 years  (don't forget the original game came out in 2004 so it is even more) so if you already decided to play you won't really get disapointed.[/h1] "There is only war" (immersion) [/h1]Ok the game can give you back the Wh 40k feeling better than anything: blood, gore, execute anymations, perfect voice actors, FOR THE EMPEROR BABY 11/10.[/h1] "Claim it in the name of the Emperor!" (campaign and single player matches)[/h1]The game mode which mocked campaign. Is basickly a VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY simplified version of total war where you have to conquer the land in a TBS map and play through battles in real time. You can also improove your general's wargear by counquesting. Great opportunity to try different races against each other nothing more nothing less. (ahh you expected lore? well that's a shame cause you won't get any in this game. Even Dark Crused had some coool quotes bettween different generals which has gone here.)There are Shcirmish maches which are as usual matches against AI in multi maps.The AI is well scaled... sometimes dumb sometimes not. All in all not bad.Campaign: 4/10 [/h1] This is it men, the moment of glory "(multiplayer)"9 races. NIne fukking races. I don't know how but they are balanced (ok ok. some people can argue but in paper they are balanced in reality the only problem is that the players can't really know how should they play serteand factions.)Orks are the red army 2.0.Space Marines are musculer peace makers with very accurat but small group of soldiers.Chaos is similar to S.M. but less arranged and they have daemons.Imperial guards are the late game (which is usually the 8th minute) bullies.Eldar: never played eldar but they have stealth and they are quick.Necron super strong rush. don't need strategic point for recourse. Badass robots.Tau: good ranged and melle mixture. They aren't the best at anything but they have super long range. ahh and NO TURETTS BUT.The two new factions. Well I think they are totaly unreasonable.Because the Dark Eldars are OP And the sisters are (who plays them ?)  then say me how they are ment to be played. (are they girl space marines?)They just aren't as well made as the 7 above.But well let's talk a slightly bit about multi.Yu can play annihillation in deathmatch, 1v1, teamdeatchmatch (simple and usuall) There supposed to be take and hold victories too but honestly I never seen anybody playing them :/.The players are or veterans or new guys. (like myself)I never had any problems about communications and I never saw anyone being offensive if this matters.There can be some lagg but I get used to it after 2 matches.Balance and factions: 8/10[/h1]"You cannot immagine what we have seen with our eyes" (Graphichs)[/h1]2004 engine did you waiting for?Graphichs and animations are bad but the textures are VERY WELL made so the game looks better than some of its coevals. You can make your own colour variations.Overall, the Graphich engine didn't age well but the textures are high quality.7/10[/h1]"shall I play the music hear then?"(soundtrack/music)[/h1]Well it is great.  :D 9/10(but sirously I can't really tell anything about music in general so I can't review this part like and expert[/h1]"DO YOU HEAR THE VOICES TOO?"(quotes ingame voices)[/h1]Ok well what do you think why am I typing qoutes instead the titles? BECAUSE THEY ARE AMAZING.I can't even tell how much time did I get virtual ♥♥♥♥♥♥ by listening to the amazing work the voice actors did with this game. Every single one of the quotes are memoable and the best ones like tzhe ork theme song or my personal favourite the quotes of the Theckpriests are shining like pearls. Making the game fun even if you lose.Everything sounds perfect the orks are funny the chaos is mad the space marines are baddases the necrons are spookie the imperial guard (my favourite if we look at the voice acting) is military and very good. If you fukking hear the gurdsmand speaking you just feeld their pain their fear their pray their hardihoodHELL this game is even woth to buy for its quotes.AMAZINGI can't say anything else.  Listen to them yourself:

			Tactical Marine Sqaud quotes from Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War "Marine Squad deployed." "Charge!" "Engaging the enemy." "Attacking as ordered." "Commencing attack." "None shall stop us!" "We will...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qnr4wYZrUjghttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FFcogzl_RKY  40.000/10[/h1] FOR. THE. EMPEROR[/h1]+AMAZING voices+good music+nice and unusal gameplay (ok well now it isn't that unusual but in that time)+pretty go community +baddass characters+Warhammer 40k+RTS (yes unfortunately this is a pro there are so few of them :(      )+Imperial fukking guard..... I am so sorry but if I love them ?+nice textures+9 farely unique factions[/h1]FORTHEDARKGODS[/h1]-old engine-no campaign in  my eyes-VERY FEW MULTIPLAYER GAMERS VERY VERY FEWNEVER FORGET THIS THERE ARE FEWI repeat FEW-There aren't as many strategic choise as in a Starcraft.[/h1] Final Verdict 9/10 all time classic [/h1] Hope you liked the review have a wonderfull day and good bye.PS: yes I know my english is bad and I am sure I missclicked many of the letters sorry for that

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I rate the game Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War - Soulstorm 4/5. Good. Far from being just a mere expansion, this game is more than large enough to be an entire game in its own right with multiple factions and a different ending for each faction. This game lets you play full single player campaigns as The Imperial Guard, The Blood Ravens Space Marines, The Adeptus Sorroritas chapter of The Bloody Rose (AKA the Bolter ♥♥♥♥♥es), The forces of Chaos Undivided, The Dark Eldar, The Eldar, the Orks, The Necrons or as The Tau Empire.Of course, I played a single player campaign through as The Tau Empire (my favorite Warhammer 40k faction) and even when played (fairly leisurely though) on easy difficulty my campaign lasted for about 33 hours. There is also an extensive skirmish mode which can be played against the computer or, with the right software (such as Tunngle), with other people over the Internet. Because of all the factions you can possibly choose to play as, this is a very replayable game (and the skirmish mode has a LOT of maps to play on including all the old maps from previous Dawn of War add-ons and expansions) but this game can, at times, suffer from a sense of severe repetition and of course, it helps a lot of you like Command and Conquer style "RTS" (Real time Strategy as they are called) games. RTS games are not really my main thing and I'm honestly not that great at them.The (Greater) Good:+This game has all the benefits and most of the weaknesses of Warhammer 40k Dark Crusade. For the most part, this game is simply longer. If you wanted to play a Dawn of War game which is like Dark Crusade this is the game for you. The wonderful options and strategic freedom provided by the global tactical map featured in Dark Crusade returns in Soulstorm. All RTS games should give you the excellent degree of strategic freedom of choosing which battles to fight and in what order which this game gives you. The global tactical map which you use between battles also does a wonderful job of giving you a star-system wide understanding of what is going on in the war. If only Command and Conquer or Homeworld had given me this degree of choice. (I loved the Homeworld games but the degree of strategic choice offered in Soulstorm (and Dark Crusade for that matter) blows the linear campaigns of other RTS games away and ideally should set a whole new standard of freedom). +The controls are fairly intuitive and standard for a RTS game making it easy to learn.+Just as in Dark Crusade, Soulstorm reminds you to save it whenever you quit and never seems to freeze up. Indeed, I found very, very few bugs (other than units with long range being able to shoot through solid walls and a few basic path-finding problems in certain maps). This game never froze up for me.+The multiplayer mode options included in this game are truly extensive and there are a wide variety of multiplayer battlefields to fight on for 2 to 8 players at a time (Just like in Dark Crusade).+The game menus are very well designed and the "cute" little imperial thoughts for the day persist in this game on the main menu and on the game exit menu.Mediocre stuff:+/- The game has certain "honor guard" units which can be taken with you from battle to battle in a somewhat persistent manner. I love persistent armies in RTS games as they offer a whole extra degree of realistic tactical complexity. The armies in Soulstorm (and Dark Crusade) are only mildly persistent from one battle to another. Only certain squads are retained and brought with you into the next offensive. Most other units you "created" or called in during the battle vanish completely causing you to need to go through the process of "creating" the units command and conquer style all over gain during the next battle. This is totally unrealistic and I have begun to hate this common gameplay element in RTS increasingly as time goes by. I could understand that early computers might not have been able to keep track of every single unit you made from one battle to the next (MAYBE) but now games should remember every unit you ever called in or created and put those units to use in the next battle to lower the game's feeling of repetition. I want armies which have units which persist from one battle to another (or at least an option for the game to allow this).+/-The Adeptus Sorroritas and the Dark Eldar factions and the new "air" units (though they control just like ground units and even hover in place and don't act at all like actual air units should) are welcome additions. The "air" units however are a disappointment. When I think of air power I think of massive airstrikes or aircraft units which make continual strafing and bombing runs and so forth, not little hovering vehicles (like helicopters at best) which I can send here or there like any other light tank.+/- The soundtrack is adequate (the Tau theme is very fitting and probably the best new piece of music in this game) but as before it is largely boring and derivative (but not obnoxious, unless an Adeptus Sorroritas theme is playing) and sets the mood well).Bad stuff:-As is true in any other part of Dawn of War I, the graphics, especially by today's standards are adequate but mediocre and the color scheme seems a bit bland, including a wide range of beige and gray colors. It's odd to try to describe but the colors in this game tend towards faded colors as if they were being filtered through parchment. This might have been done on purpose but it does not suit some factions very well (like the Necrons or the Tau). The landscapes are particularly drab. The camera can be zoomed very far in and re-angled to any perspective but dense fog prevents you from being able to see anything approaching the whole battlefield in the main viewscreen. -Like in any other Dawn of War I game or expansion the view can never be zoomed out very far which can make selecting large numbers of units at a time (which is something I love to do to ensure that different types of units properly reinforce one another when I have a large army) pretty problematic. The perspective issues come together to severely limit how epic the battles can feel and instead make them feel more like a table-top RPG than I think a videogame should. As in Dawn of War, In Dark Crusade you always feel as though every battle is just a minor skirmish in the overall war because graphically, it always looks that way. This is a common problem in most RTS games however, even to this day. Perhaps this was remedied in Supreme Commander (and I know it was Remedied in the Homeworld games) but most RTS games definitely have this problem.-Like in Dark Crusade each faction has but one victorious single-player campaign ending. If your faction is defeated in the campaign you are essentially asked if you want to be booted out to the main menu. There is no bad ending, no final monologue showing what happens because you failed. Just a menu.-You cannot play through the single-player campaign mode either cooperatively or otherwise which is really too bad because this would have made for a great, ongoing, persistent multiplayer mode (Just like in Dark Crusade).-This game's battles, being very similar to battles found in most Command and Conquer games, are fairly repetitious. You need to get your little infantry units out and capture strategic points (or supplies as the case may be) early or else you will lose. There is no other really viable way to play and as a result your tactical options are always limited and unrealistic. In real life, well...a lot of things are different but its is ludicrous to have to capture resources during a battle to decide what forces you will get during that same battle. The forces you have and the resources you have access to in one battle should be primarily decided based on what occurred in the battle which occurred previously, NOT the battle you are playing now.

												War never changes you say? How about world where Peace is just not an option? One of the last good Relic games (mostly because Iron Lore involvment) The game where regiment of troopers screeming "FOR THE EMPROOOAAHHH" beating souslees death machines. Even without truly great mods battle always can become big and yet doesnt require of you Starcraft RPM action. And of course here is the game with 9 nations (3 of them also could count as one) are mostly well balanced which bring you to good multiplayer action (if it had one cause now only rly old players are there which means 5-10 min gg no matter what). Yet there one big downside of this game. In turns of stayin near to source and Codex (at that time) game fails very hard. 												Amazing game. The pinicle of the series.Nice campaign system that takes what the previous expansions did and expands it on every front.Sadly...Thanks to some unknown reason, someone at Sega (?), has disconnected the confirmation method to unlock the factions from the side games: Winter Assualt and Dark Crusade.  No Necrons, Imperial Guard or Tau, on multiplayer, even if you already bought those games which still advertise this as a selling point.Unless this is a problem, if single player campaigns with medium stories is your thing (note all races are allowed in offline v cpu skrimish), highly recommended.If you like multiplayer, coop or otherwise, avoid until the developers or the forces that be resolve what is a damn annoying bug. Writing this as a negative review, was hard.  I love this game, but damn, I do hate it when such a simple fault steals away that which you bought and paid for...

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
 WAAAAAAUUUUGHHHWell this is a surprise. If uyou plaued Dark Crusade this is pretty much the same game, just layed out on a different map. You are technically conquering planets but in reality it's the same mechanics as Dark Crusade. One change is that each race nopw has it's own unique power which you can get by conquering them; a welcome change from Dark Crusade.Amnother change is defense. You will always start out with  just your base, which I suppose majkes things a little easier . No ssuper enemy entrenchments like the last time. In factm, that's half the issue. The game is unbelievably easy compared to the previous, but then again that game was only easy due to the egregious cheating done by the AI.For a game with so much packed it, it's rather odd that it should feel spread thin, but that is what it feels like I'm afraid. Wirth a total of 9 races no race feels truly distinct beyond aesthetics.Still this is a solid game for any RTS fan.

Don't punish legitimate customers by patching out features that make the game fun and forcing them to look for alternatives, legit or not.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												So, I wanted to get this game for a long time because I love Warhammer 40k (like most people who play these games) and The Sisters of Battle are my favorite faction in the imperium and I was super bummed to find out that they were not in the original Dawn of War. When I heared that Soulstorm has playable Sisters, I jumped on that like a fat kid on cake.Well... after over 10 Hours of playtime, I'm angry and frustraded. I don't really play much multiplayer, I just prefere singleplayer... but... well... this game is just too frustrating and hard. I like the Idea of the campaign mode, but the execution is horrible. It is a cool concept: You pick your side in the conflict, you have your warlord that you can equip with gear and maintain an honor guard... and you generally try to conquer your way through this planetary system. You fight your opponents in little skirmish type battles and try to win. Every win nets you new perks and that is neat. So Obviously, I played Sisters of Battle. As the Sisters, you start on the same planet as the Imperial Guard and that will be your first opponent. Now, I was already kinda disappointed that I also had to fight Imperial forces but oh well. Now, You would think that, because it is just the start of the game, you could just rush through the first few encounters and get to the hard part later, right? I got stomped in the first mission. Maybe it was because I didn't knew what I was really doing but they just pushed me into my base and I couldn't do anything but watch the guard with all their troops rush me to death. I retried and won, but it still wasn't easy. I basically had to rush them as fast as possible with as many sisters as possible or I was mayorly screwed. After some more battles against the guard and getting really tired of their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, I finally managed to push them back to their base. Alright. Now, every faction has their own base where you have a special mission with special objectives to win. This is where things turned for the worse. The mission is basically neigh impossible. You are beset on all sides with guardsman, you have to stop a convey that can spawn from multiple locations before it reaches the base otherwise the guard gets a BANEBLADE, you are constantly fighting against the clock because after a while they start pumping out more and more dangerous units (not to mention that they send those units after you mercilessly), you can't really capture anything because you are on a timer basically, you have to multitask all the time because you can be attacked from anywhere at anytime and not even your base is really safe and while trying to manage all that, there comes a giant artillery cannon that will blast an entire squad in one shot and to stop it you have to walk through a gauntlet of turrets, guardsmen, tanks, sentinels and more more more turrets. It is literal hell and not fun. I tried this mission over and over and over for 8 Hours before I decided that this is not worth my time and I tried to cheat... and the game wouldn't even give me that way out.This is the worst time I had in a long time. Not because the game itself is bad... it is based on dawn of war and has my favorite faction in it so it gets a gold star in raw gameplay... but because the missions are insanely hard and the AI is horrendesly unforgiving on normal and brutally unbeliveably stupid on easy. I also tried skirmish matches (to try out my second to favorite faction, the Tau), set AI difficulty to normal and I got blasted harder than I have ever been blasted by a human opponent. So, I thought I'd try easy... the enemy did not try to capture any points, their guys never left the base and they never bought upgrades. It was boring to say the least. Why is this game this bad?I had fun with Dawn of War and Dawn of War 2 is also really really fun, why does the only game in the series with my favorite faction suck so much? I will never understand.Do yourself a favor and don't play this game if you don't want to play it multiplayer. It is just not worth the anger it causes. Here is hope that Dawn of War 3 will be fun and maybe even get a Sisters DLC or something.... it would at least make up somewhat for all the frustrating hours I poured into this game...

												PROS:- Campaigns now have more varied non-stronghold missions than the simple ol' Annihilate condition.- Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle are rather interesting new factions to play, both with rather unique mechanics.- Strongholds in campaign are harder than ever, with a different difficulty focus - rather than having an initial difficult wave and becoming gradually easier, difficulty of waves ramps up over the course of the game.CONS- Aerial units for the older factions were very clearly added as a promotion for Games Workshop itself, which was releasing kits of flyers at the time; unfortunately, they add rather little to the game (thematically there were far less iconic than many other potential options), are poorly adapted for the game engine (mechanics-wise, they are simply units which hover, and are rendered as such) and feel forced and limited in scope by the minimalistic single-aircraft-added-to-each-faction theme. (Flyers should have been in development longer to avoid them being "floating vehicles", and several should've been added for them to make any impact. Soulstorm was released before the rise of DLC as a common occurence, but a few aircraft added by patch would've gone a long way.)- Campaign is more mind-numbingly tedious than ever, with the decision to scrap persistent buildings between games removing what little element of meta-strategy exists and the Ancient Gate mechanic essentially reducing campaign difficulty outside of Strongholds.- The campaign plot is convoluted (cut off by a Warp Storm which allows every race bar Tyranids into the system? Huh?) and the characters rather dislikeable.VERDICT:Play it for Skirmish/Multiplayer (previous expansions and mods theretofor lacked Dark Eldar entirely!) or use it for mods (Inquisition Daemonhunt surpasses the base game in quality of models and design, and the Witch Hunters Mod puts the Sisters of Battle of Soulstorm to shame!), but don't expect an exceptionally engaging campaign mode or major gameplay changes. The campaign system of Dark Crusade was novel then, the unit additions to previous factions satisfactory and the Tau Empire and Necrons factions quirky enough; but for Soulstorm, the novelty had worn out, and the result lacked the lustre of previous entries. The game is no worse than previous entries (albeit no better), but its value is subjective based on how much you value the meagre gameplay changes and modestly great new factions.

content:
Posted: March 27
												Don't buy this game, just get DC instead.The sisters of battle, Dark Eldar, and flying units arn't worth the broken♥♥♥♥♥mechanics and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ A.I.Why do I say Broken? Because what the devs did is instead of making a more intelligent A.I is they punished the player. That is a big no-no. NEVER gimp the player just to make your game harder. Remember how in DC when you took land all the buildings you built would stay there, that way in case you got invaded they were there and ready? Kiss that goodbye. Now, once you take the land all your buildings are deleted. Why? Don't ask me, but it makes defensive battle exactly the same as offensive battles. But thats not all. Not ONLY are your bases whisked away as if they have other places to be after the battle, causing you to start every game from scratch, but the computer can START with 2 bases when THEY are attacking YOU! For what reason? Because the devs were to lazy to make a compitent system so they punish the player for playing the game. It becomes incredibly frustrating when you have JUST taken control of a place, only to have the computer counter-attack forcing you into the exact same battle exept worse because now the enemy will be constantly assulting you with endgame units before the clock hits 1 minute you preventing you from building your base up. This makes it very easy to become locked in place and unable to progress any further in your campaign One good part of this game is the strongholds. Every stronghold is sufficiantly unique and somewhat challenging, though some are rather annoying, like the eldar's hold. However these are also where the games storytelling comes in and it's absolute crap. For instance, when you take the Ork stronghold it tells you that Gorgutz "somehow" escapes. Somehow? SOMEHOW? Come on man give me some details! Did he have his mecboyz make him a makeshift spacecraft and call in the flash Gitz to pick him up? Did he disapear into the warp? Another exapmle is the necron intro. "Nobody knows why the necrons awoke," What? Nobody knows? It seems like the Eldar know why they're there but according to the writers "nobody knows?" Who the hell wrote this stuff?Aside from what I've wrote there are some odd audio glitches but other than that it's a pretty standard warhammer 40k game. If you have to make a choice between this and Dark Crusaide, get DC. It's better and more fair in every possable way.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Soulstorm is the latest and most-played expansion pack to Dawn of War. It offers the most balance, though it's still one of the less balanced RTS games, and it has the most races.The Warhammer 40K really comes to live in this game, with memorable quotes from units and mouth-watering visuals as lasers and rockets fly. Units have special kill animations during battles in melee, making them visually impressive whether you're zoomed out or zoomed in. Each of the many factions plays very differently, from the Orks and their unit-swarming powers to the Necrons and their utterly free, but slow, units.There's a replayable campaign in Soulstorm, similar to the one offered in Dark Crusade, but most players will find their playtime in skirmishes and online. I highly reccomend playing with friends if you aren't competitive. Also of note, Soulstorm has a very impressive free mod named Codex that adds -a ton- of variety and also has options to increase the population limits on battles, allowing giant wars worthy of the Warhammer name. This mod is well worth looking into once you're done with the vanilla game.

												I would only recommend this game to anyone if previously they have got all of DoW installments, (Original, Winter Assault, Dark Crusade) and only because then you get all of the races. The races are slightly imbalanced, however, on a big map with four plus players, this game becomes more intense as a strategy than any fast paced shooter. You micromanage like crazy, biuld units, attack, retreat ,upgrade , capture, hold, lose, take back, scout, use abilities (a mind blowing amount of them too)... And then an epic battle happens with giant Relic units and dozens of different troops and troop types. Even though DoW2 is better in physics and engine and etc. it does not have the same drive as this game... Speaking of Single player, Dark Crusade is probably the best, however for more in-depth experience I prefer the winter assault, although it is more linear.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												"Our weapons are terror, darkness and SPEED!"Soulstorm is the last expansion for the original Dawn of War. However, instead of a last hurrah in honour of the glorious emperor of mindkind, it just a convoluted mess of gimmicks and glitches. Before we discuss the technicalities, lets look at the content. Soulstorm adds two new races to Dawn of War: The Sisters of Battle, and the Dark Eldar. Neither are genuinely unique races, but they are different from the race their branched out of. The Sisters are a cult of fanatics who wield a wide assortment of flamethrowers and use divine powers to make themselves invincible. The Dark Eldar on the other hand are all about speed and hit and run tactics. Each race also gets a new airplane unit which reflects the race's general playstyle. Both of the new races also come with their own unique resource that can be spent to unleash special abilities on the field. Both races feel rather uninteresting. The Sisters feel space marines without the brawn, while the Dark Eldar feel like a swarm of gnats that cannot really put out any damage.Unfortunately, the problems have only just begun. The expansion is unfinished; many abilities and weapons just don't do anything. The guns on some aircraft really do no damage, while other abilities just stack ad infinitum to create an indestructible unit. It is a shame, because the campaign tries to go above and beyond what Dark Crusade had set up. More planets, more abilities, more options. However, just like I mentioned before, a lot of it just doesn't work properly. To be fair, Soulstorm's development was a mess and as a result the final product is a mess. It functions, but only barely. Playing Soulstorm is like driving a Ferrari with its tyres deflated; You may have the best car in the world, but you just can't enjoy it to the fullest because there is a glaring fault wherever, and whatever you do.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												This game has numerous bugs.1)when you try to move your army by clicking on a location,your army tends not to go where it's supposed to go to.Instead it spreads itself over a large area instead of trying its best to gather in one spot,even when there is sufficient space to gather.2) multiple instances of grouped units not moving at all after clicking on a location3) multiple instances of units at the back not attacking once some units at the front have engaged the enemy.4)Multiple instances of barracks not loading the infantry screen, resulting in the players not being able to buy units5)multiple instances of cadre headquarters not displaying the screen, resulting in players not being able to buy builders/stealth teams6)multiple instances of builders not loading anything, resulting in players not being able to build anymore structuresApart from bugs, the difficulty in conquering strongholds in single player campaign is way too high. despite having almost all wargear, all honor guards, the game is too difficult as you start off with a newly established base and some builders, while your enemy starts off with multiple developed bases,multiple developed defenses and elite troops right off the start.Not only do you get attacked by troops from the start, you still have to prevent the computer from securing 3/5 critical locations so that they do not get the win. Tier2/3 computer troops vs tier 1 troops from the get-go. Fun times.

												Is the base game worth it?NO, NO IT ISN'T. The base game is absolutely horrible, the campaign being absolutely boring and frustrating. The balance of the races and the inclusion of flying units make the multiplayer worse than Dark Crusade. content:
Posted: November 12, 2012
												Soulstorm is pretty much a carbon copy of Dark Crusade. It's a standalone expansion to Dawn of War that adds two new races and using the new non-linear Grand Strategy style campaign map that THQ have grown so fond of.Like in Dark Crusade there is really no learning curve for new players. You are thrown directly into the fray with no introduction to the gameplay, units or technologies and just have to wing it as best you can. Also like in Dark Crusade you can only use the new races in multi-player unless you already own the previous Dawn of War games which is really a bummer for anyone that buys this with the intention to play with friends.The single-player is the continued development of Dark Crusade and the campaign works much the same way. The introduction of two new factions have made the map a bit bigger and this doesn't help as it only adds more grind. Playing through the single-player is essentially a progression of skirmish maps and it becomes boring, very fast. The stronghold maps are quite entertaining but they are the only fun thing in the campaign so you'll often find yourself dreading going into battle against yet another pointless incursion into your territory.The new factions introduced in Soulstorm aren't quite as interesting as the ones introduced in Dark Crusade either. Firstly you have the Sisters of Battle which are essentially the super fanatical military arm of the "Ordo Hereticus" in the Empire of Man. Essentially they are the people you send when it's time to massacre your own people in great numbers. They have no remorse and will willing sacrifice anyone in the name of the Emperor. In game they play much like the Space Marines, in fact they are eerily similar in terms of unit composition to the regular Space Marines, only with a somewhat disturbing tendency towards pyromania.The second new faction are the Dark Eldar which are what the Chaos Space Marines to the Eldar. Unfortunately they are not nearly as cool or as interesting. They feel like some Eldar went and smoked some Chaos but forgot to inhale. In terms of gameplay they are little more interesting than the Sisters of Battle with their fast moving units but they don't really add too much to the formula.Both factions read really well in the WH40K universe but their implementation in the Dawn of War franchise feels really poor. They just lose so much of their personality when they don't have any proper campaigns, you never feel the fanaticism of the sisters or the sadomasochism of the Dark Eldar.Sound and graphics are solid as always but as nothing new is being added it's beginning to feel a little stale.Although this installment maintains that special WH40K feel that I enjoy so much it, much like the rest of the game, has begun to feel a little stale. No new story or interesting characters have been introduced since Winter Assault and there really isn't much left.Soulstorm feels like a last attempt at squeaking out the last bit of money from Dawn of War before THQ moves on to making a proper sequel.

number of helpful: 2 of 22 people (9%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14
Positives* It is a better than average game. Buy on sale, not at full price.* As an RTS fan I can say that this game has an interesting take on the subject and is fun; that being said I've never played multiplayer, so my review is based on single player only. * The single player campaign I felt was decent, not the best. I feel that the missions took too long in order to properly enjoy the story.Negatives* Single player campaign missions took too long in most cases, and made it difficult to become fully engaged into the story. Thus the story became not enjoyable.* The characters didn't grab my attention as much compared to the Dawn of War 2. The story was simple, with obvious twists; and didn't teach enough about the Warhammer Universe or history to really get me into that world. That being said I did enjoy Gabriel Angelos, but he wasn't in the expansions!* By comparison, I'd rather spend an hour listening to a documentary about the imperium of man, and the empire, than spending an hour on a single mission.* No steam achievements.ResultDoW 1 and DLC = 6/10.If you must play this game, buy it on sale and not at full price. I also highly recommend Dawn of War 2 instead; although base building is removed, I feel it is the superior game for its story.Additional NoteSeems people don't like my review, please inform me why in the comments, thank you.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												Overall, a fun time, especially if you are getting tired of Starcraft and C&C.Not quite as good as the core game or Imperial Guard expansion. No better or worse than the Dark Crusade, just different. They added two more races but the campaign is like Dark Crusade: You try to take over all zones in a star system. Most of the maps are boring, and defending your areas multiple times per round can be tiresome. On Easy the AI is a joke, and from Medium upwards the AI is brutally efficient. Dark Eldar in particular have a bad habit of standing around doing nothing.However, theres plenty of options for Skirmish, and a LOT of maps. More than any previous version of the game. This will probably be your default program for multiplayer and AI single player, as it has all the factions and all the maps.But if you want a solid campaign experience on any difficulty, you need to play the Gold edition.

Posted: May 23, 2014
												NOTE: This is the final version of Dawn of War, and really the only one you need. Dawn of War had four races. Each expansion pack added at least one additional race. Soul Storm was the final expansion, and includes all of the races for the game (except Tyrannids, but there's a great mod that adds them!) The only things it lacks are the individual campaigns from the expansions, but frankly, they're not interesting enough to bother with. JUST BUY SOULSTORM, and you've got everything you need.Alright, the review. Dawn of War is a real-time strategy game the relies very heavily on position. Unlike most RTS games, where you can simply hunker down and build up an army, here you have to go looking for the scarce resources you need. That means taking risks. Once you have what you need, you get to see a Warhammer 40,000 army in action in a way never before seen. You move your troops in squads, and those squads act on their own. You can only do so much; march them into certain death and they'll break, panic, and end up getting destroyed. You are very much the commander here, not a fighting participant, and your orders mean less than the situation in front of them. The won't retreat, but poorly thought out orders mean a quick death.In terms of appearance, the game is authentic to the table-top models. The Space Marines look clunky, the Necrons like an ancient Egyptian nightmare, and so forth. The models are well detailed and reasonably individual. When standing idle, they look around, check their weapons, and do what idle solders do. When in battle, they really look like they're fighting it out, making contact with their enemies, and experiencing the impact of their enemy's weapons. The sound is about what you'd expect. Unit acknowledgments are race specific, so the Space Marines end up sounding like the fanatical, long-lived Army of the Damned they are. The Eldar come off as arrogant. The Chaos forces sound a lot like that guy in your office who has been stuck at the same job for twenty years, hates life, and has sworn allegiance to the terrible, dark gods. (Sorry, is that only this one guy I know?) In the end, the audio cues do what they're supposed to; remind you that there are no good guys in Warhammer 40K. The music is, in a word, generic. The campaign in Soulstorm is much as it was in the previous expansion; a territory-hopping game stretched over several planets. Each race takes turns moving, reinforcing, and attacking. It's nothing special, but an enjoyable way to learn all the races. In the end, I highly recommend this game.

												Although growing old in years, DoW is a landmark RTS and is the best WH40K game that has been made in terms of sheer content and variety. Whilst the campaign is lacklustre, having 9 races that play very differently is an incredible feat, backed up by just how much extra content you can find from the mod scene. The game was launched with ease of modding in mind and as such you can massively expand the game into the most comprehensive WH40K game that has ever been made, and possibly will ever be.

Posted: March 17, 2014
												An excellent strategy game. It's resources are based on capturing strategic locations and fortifying them with listening posts which forces you to get out there and fight. Moral is also a significant factor, and special weapons can help to break enemy moral making them easier to kill and reducing their damage which adds another layer to the available tactics. There are also a myriad different races to choose from if you own all the expansions, which are well worth it in my opinion. In this RTS fortune truly favors the bold. My only complaint was that Dawn of War never released Tyranids, and I have vowed never to buy another Games Workshop game until the finish off this series properly.

Posted: December 6, 2014
												Buy this game and it's expansions when they get on sale, and install the Ultimate Apocalypse Mod and it's map packs. You will then have *the* best RTS game. The Warhammer: 40k universe is colorful, unique and darkly beautiful, and the plethora of unique factions in this game represent this very well. Dawn of War is easy to understand and tough to master, with hundreds of units and dozens of unique battlefield types that take you to demolished gothic cities, frozen tundras, dense jungles, volcanic wastelands and lifeless moons to name a few.Gameplay is tactical yet simple, with upgrades available for each unit and parts of the terrain that can be used to give units defensive bonuses, such as blown-out craters. Different unit types are more effective against others, making for a rock-paper-scissors dynamic that requires you to carefully choose your targets.You can also customize your armies with different color schemes, banners and insignias for your buildings and units.Multiplayer battles with friends against the computer will be crazy amounts of fun.Long live the Emperor/10

Posted: December 30, 2015
												This game, plus the Ultimate Apocalypse mod, makes it insane and amazing at the same time, all the races (which assuming you own the games already you can use a race unlocker with the serial number for the games to unlock all the races in the game, thus you need not have the other games installed, useful tip for saving HDD space).I only play this on Hard with the UA mod installed now, and with all the new models, all the new modes of game play and all the massive array of maps you can get for this game, its without a doubt one of the best RTS games out there, mainly for gameplay, stategy and the shere amount of bodies you can pile up on the battlefieldRaces in the UA mod and all the other games installed or unlocked with race unlocker would include:Imperial Guard: Defensive bunch, but you do need to expand and then defend with them, so loads of turrets and walls.Sisters of Battle: Offensive ranged race, do have melee capability but similar in offensive capability to the Space Marines.Space Marines: Offensive predominantly ranged, though can melee and are an awesome race to play as.Inquisition Daemon Hunters: Offensive and Defensive, so balanced, harder to play as but specialise in anti demon or monster weaponary, so you;'d use these against, chaos, chaos daemons, orks and tyranids.Eldar: Stealthy and very much infiltrate and move around race, can be devastating if you know how to use them correctly, you'll always be moving your base around with them.Dark Eldar: Expect alot of blood and alot of murder with these guys, again like eldar these are quick brutal attack then flee again race, but essentially fleeing with the souls of your foes to feed the war effort.Necrons: A powerful offensive race, very very powerful at the early stage and even more so at later stage of the game, can be used for defence as well. effective against everything.Chaos: Offensive ranged, or melee, effective against all. Chaos Daemons: Very very powerful race at the moment would destroy most races in 1 vs 1, hell even 1 vs 2 is hard with them, they are obviously countered by the Inquistion race but are still hard to defeat, very very offensive race.Orks: Mass swarm type game play, you'll build numbers then just swarm your enemy, easy to kill any single unit but in a massive bulk swarm they can overrun most other races defenses, offensive race.Tau: Offensive or Defensive so balanced, you can build great barriers to defend your base or send in semi organic armoured units into the fray, predominantly ranged though the kroot upgrade you can build more on the lines of melee units.Tyranids: haha these are basically monsters, they are a massive swarm army and very devastating in battle, if you are to go against these its best to have a massive line of defensive turrets and alot of ranged units with melee in the front to defend the ranged, they swarm on an epic scale. Very offensive race.Anyway I'd highly recommend this game, I've had 100's of hours in it, mainly outside of steam and coop with a buddy on the online servers and battle it out on a custom map whether downloaded or you've made it yourself, a very very good game overall.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Having played all of the other Dawn of War games, this one certainly seems to be the weakest of the series.  Don't get me wrong, it's still a load of fun, but when compared to the other installments in the series, this one feels a bit phoned in.  If you've ever played Dark Crusade, it's very much like that.  But, in case you haven't, in Soulstorm you choose one of nine factions to lead to victory over the Kaurava system.  The system is divided into territories spanned across 4 planets and 3 moons.  Each faction starts controlling a certain number of territories, whereas the player starts with only a single territory.  Each faction must then battle it out for control of each territory in the system.  You defeat other factions by conquering their primary territory, known as their stronghold.  In Dark Crusade the campaign played out in much the same fashion, but over a single planet rather than a system.  Furthermore, the backstory for the planet and each of the individual territories felt much more fleshed out in Dark Crusade.  The reasoning for the presence of each faction was better explained and the entire game just seemd to have more personality.Aside from this, Soulstorm is really just more of the same.  And that's great if you're a Dawn of War fan.  It's great to finally see the Adepta Sororitas (Sisters of Battle) added to the game and the gameplay works just as well as it ever has.Ultimately, I would recommend this game but only if you enjoyed the other Dawn of War installments.  If this is your first introduction to the Dawn of War Series, I would strongly recommend playing the other games first.

												This game is awesome.  It encourages you to go out and capture a significant portion of the map and take the fight to strategic points all over the game field.  Fighters are purchased in squads meaning that they are easier to manage than if they were in single dudes.  Squad upgrades are a thing.  so I can have one squad of marines with flamers and another with bolters.  The campaign is awesome.  Its a little like risk.  It allows you to get an honor guard who will start in play with your commander.  Also, your commander can get sick upgrades throughout the campaign.  Each faction you conquer gives you a unique and cool bonus relating to the over all campaign.  also, there are a lot of factions, each very different from the others.  for example, one faction's first unit is a stealth unit.  another straight up doesn't use one of the basic resources.  The only con is that with the multitude of factions, they aren't perfectly balanced.  It does not ruin the game thoughA really creative and cool game that has kept me entertained for years.

Posted: August 9, 2013
												The Dawn of War series (The original, Winter Assault, Dark Crusade, and Soulstorm) is one of the most incredible RTSes out there. It has fluid action, unit counters that force tactical play, and it even allows one of the rarest options in any RTS. . Persistant corpses. You can actually count (or lose count of) the number of bodies that litter a battlefield. Oddly, this is a feature I wish more RTSes had. I guess I'm just twisted that way.Resources are simple: You take requisition points to steadily generate requisition (the main resource) and you build generators to produce power (the secondary resource). There's good unit variety among a total of 9 factions in all if you own all of the expansions. Note that buying Soulstorm will NOT let you play factions in multiplayer which were released prior to it without CD keys for those races. You need to own a copy of each respective game to play its races in a multiplayer mode. The only gripe I have is its lack of backward compatibility with its prior games, which is a shame since you need to own those games to play those races. For example, I have been unable to get a game going with my friend because he has Dark Crusade but not Soulstorm. His game does not recognize the Soulstorm races, and we had no luck finding a patch for it. This is -very bad- for this kind of expansion style. You can however play any race in skirmish mode regardless of having prior expansions, which I also find to be a little odd, but at least you can try the races in single player.Besides my gripe on the expansions, if you want an RTS that is phenominal, I give Dawn of War two thumbs up. It currently comes with all prior expansions in one Steam pack, and Soulstorm as a seperate game. This is a must play if you are an RTS fanatic.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												This game is wonderful, and yet, it ALMOST ruined the series at the same time. Dawn of War: Soulstorm is the pinnacle of the first DoW series, with a maximum of nine races and the largest campaign. However, the new units, which are in particular, airborne units, broke the game, and to this day get stuck in impassable terrain and will need to be executed and re-built to provide any usefulness whatsoever. Now that we've gotten past that gripe, let me brag about this game for a while. The visuals aren't Crysis or Battlefield tier, but they're still not half-bad for a game as old as it is. The story had classic Warhammer elements, and has a maximum of nine endings, with each ending depending on what race you play. And the mods. I have maybe 15 mods on this game, which add anything from races to units to nukes (look up the Apocalypse Mod; it is glorious). So, Soulstorm, on it's own, is a decent game. Mod it, and it may as well have just come out yesterday.

Posted: March 14
												So many armies to play with, so many maps, so many scenarios you could play out, Multiplayer is a blast!Every army plays differently, all holding a different play style for everyone to explore. There is often so many ways to approach an enemy team, you could send in a massive group of infantry and tanks, you could bomb them from afar, you could slowly take the land for yourself to win a battle of attrition, or you simply focus on defense. 8/10Graphics do show it's age at times, but not enough to hinder the gameplay or fun. The Enemy AI is either extremely hard, or extremely easy depending how you set the difficulty. Worth the 12 bucks, but if there's a big discount on the 40k franchise like there was a while back, just buy all the games at one time. I spent about 8 bucks on all the DOW 1 games and the first DOW 2.

Posted: August 9, 2013
												The Dawn of War series (The original, Winter Assault, Dark Crusade, and Soulstorm) is one of the most incredible RTSes out there. It has fluid action, unit counters that force tactical play, and it even allows one of the rarest options in any RTS. . Persistant corpses. You can actually count (or lose count of) the number of bodies that litter a battlefield. Oddly, this is a feature I wish more RTSes had. I guess I'm just twisted that way.Resources are simple: You take requisition points to steadily generate requisition (the main resource) and you build generators to produce power (the secondary resource). There's good unit variety among a total of 9 factions in all if you own all of the expansions. Note that buying Soulstorm will NOT let you play factions in multiplayer which were released prior to it without CD keys for those races. You need to own a copy of each respective game to play its races in a multiplayer mode. The only gripe I have is its lack of backward compatibility with its prior games, which is a shame since you need to own those games to play those races. For example, I have been unable to get a game going with my friend because he has Dark Crusade but not Soulstorm. His game does not recognize the Soulstorm races, and we had no luck finding a patch for it. This is -very bad- for this kind of expansion style. You can however play any race in skirmish mode regardless of having prior expansions, which I also find to be a little odd, but at least you can try the races in single player.Besides my gripe on the expansions, if you want an RTS that is phenominal, I give Dawn of War two thumbs up. It currently comes with all prior expansions in one Steam pack, and Soulstorm as a seperate game. This is a must play if you are an RTS fanatic.

Posted: December 6, 2014
												Buy this game and it's expansions when they get on sale, and install the Ultimate Apocalypse Mod and it's map packs. You will then have *the* best RTS game. The Warhammer: 40k universe is colorful, unique and darkly beautiful, and the plethora of unique factions in this game represent this very well. Dawn of War is easy to understand and tough to master, with hundreds of units and dozens of unique battlefield types that take you to demolished gothic cities, frozen tundras, dense jungles, volcanic wastelands and lifeless moons to name a few.Gameplay is tactical yet simple, with upgrades available for each unit and parts of the terrain that can be used to give units defensive bonuses, such as blown-out craters. Different unit types are more effective against others, making for a rock-paper-scissors dynamic that requires you to carefully choose your targets.You can also customize your armies with different color schemes, banners and insignias for your buildings and units.Multiplayer battles with friends against the computer will be crazy amounts of fun.Long live the Emperor/10

Posted: February 16, 2016
												This game in itself is very mediocre. It's an alright game, worth the money, and it can keep you entertained for a few hours. The campaign itself didn't really do it for me, the first DoW campaign was way better. Skirmish is really fun though.The balance between the races are really broken. The Tau for example don't have turrets or mines, so though they have a strong offence, their defence is is lacking and unless you constantly have an army at your disposal you're pretty much doomed. The IG is pretty much overpowered as their soldiers may be weak, but there are a lot of them, and they're quick to train and cheap as well.If you download and install the Ultimate Apocalypse mod however, this game instantly becomes a masterpiece. It fixes all problem (or most) such as the lack of turrets for the tau, and they even created their very own models! Combine it with the Tyranid mod and you get tyranids as an additional army, though I personally don't enjoy them too much.Highly recommended.

Posted: June 21, 2016
												PROs:> Action can start virtually immediately after the game starts. Most RTS games require a period of base building that can become repetitious and makes the early game boring. Soul Storm doesn't really have a lot in the way of base buildings, although it certainly is a component of the game. Unlike games such as Age of Empires, you can choose to start the combat as early as you like.> Resources are linked to map control. You actually have to play the game and compete with the other players for strategic locations. Capturing these and controlling them gives you your base resources, with the exception of necrons> EPIC MODS: Such as titanium wars and Ultimate Apocalypse mod completely overhaul the size of the game in case you ever feel like something more> No stalemates. Unlike many RTS games, where defenses can indefinitely stall the game, Armies in SS are the dominant force. The winner is the player with the biggest gun, not shield.> Logical and straigtforward mechanics: There are two types of resources and both have very different acquisition methods, exceptions for Orks and Necrons. There are many races, and all of them are as different as can reasonably be expected. The more similar a race is, the more similar their game play. Units work by building squads, not individual units, which reduces the requirements for micromanagement in fights, which speeds up the game instead of simplifying it.> Unique game play, styles and abilities for different races.> Active Online community, with plenty of competent players> Sound track is well suited, easy to listen to for hours on end.> Play with your friends for added fun> Still highly enjoyable after 100 hours (especially with mods)CONs:> Not every race is equally powerful. Dark Eldar are objectively the weakest, absolute trash. > Multitude of balance tweaks required.> Campaign is utterly lackluster, repetitious and grinding.> Camera zoom is very close, and off-putting for your first few gamesOverall: 8/10. Very satisfactory for an RTS. All RTS players ought to try this game.

Posted: May 14, 2016
												Wether your playing this game as a standalone or playing with the base games it will give you hours of playtime. Even so it is best played with the core game and the Winter assault and Dark Crusade expansions.Pros:- Good selection of playable factions. - Decent amount of maps of varying sizes.- Cood campaign that is semi-linear allowing you to choose which battles you play depending on which faction you choose.- Each faction has its own play style, strenghts, and weaknesses.- Can make your own colour schemes for use in skirmish and multiplayer modes.Cons:- Most of the factions have a very rigid playstyles.- Some factions have limited or nearly no counters to others so are easily defeated. (Stealth being the worst offender for some of the factions)- Campaign isn't really a story, but more a multi-battle system with a back story for each faction's involvement.

Posted: May 27, 2016
												I cannot tell you how many hours I've played this Relic epic of an RTS prior to Steam.  What I will say is that Relic and Steam were completely awesome in providing me with a new software key to download the game through Steam (with proof of purchase of the hard CD some years ago) and keep playing.While now dated, I must say the entire Dawn of War series, with Soulstorm as the final game in the first DoW series, was nothing but one of the finest RTS games I ever played.  I cut my teeth on the old Red Alert series, Dune 2000, and others and never really cared for the genre until Relic's classic Homeworld.  DoW brought that level of RTS to the ground in the 40K universe.  While hardcore 40K fans have far too many complaints, I think DoW's strenghts have outstripped any weaknesses.  Gameplay can be repetitive however.  DoW:Dark Crusade and Soulstorm are extremely similar in campaign play.  While Dark Crusade only covers a planet, the solar system covered in Soulstorm is only slightly larger.  The usual strategy employed in Dark Crusade of entering a  new territory and base building until you have enough of a force to conquer the enemy base is repeated with little exceptions except for the capture the flag battles for webway gates territory.I do not think the weaknesses detract from campaign play too much.  Followers of the WH40K lore are likely to enjoy playing each race through the end of their respective end game content.  It is enjoyable just for that alone.  Then there is multiplayer....

Posted: June 8, 2015
												Get the game. but get it for the mods. If you know how to handle yourself and are happy to jump through a few hoops, Install Titanium Wars, If your looking for a ezy install mod go do Ultimate Apocolypse. I won't be reviewing the game itself, there are other reviews for that, and my opinion is frank, Its the best RTS out there next to Starcraft, and not as outragously competative.  What I will be doing is compairing the two top teir mods for the game.Ultimate Apocolypse; Races it adds; Tyranids, Deamons, Ordo malleusStuff it fixes; Not much (as far as I can see)For unit comparisons I will be using Space Marines, For easy refrence.Apocolypse adds in a selection of units from table top, as well as 2 titans and fair selection of the bigger tanks. However it feels like things are missing For example, specalised heavy weapons squads along with Dreadnaught Mortis.Notes; it is easy to install however it feels like a somewhat paired down version of Titanium WarsTitanium Wars;Races Added; Tyranids, Administratum, Ordo Malleus, Wictch Hunters (Semi-conversion of the Sisters Of Battle to bring them on level)Stuff it Fixes; Removal of unbalanced Air units, AI pathing, Donatioins, and High speed calculations put in, AI is also capable of using the new units to their fullest. Unit Comparison; Almost every unit from table top, However against Apoc it only adds 1 titan for balanceing reasons. However it does allow for thing such as thunderhawk deployment of super heavy tanks alongside far more unit customization.Notes; Administratum and Ordo Malleus are huge, they feel like they should and have unique units to themselves, The voice acting isn't amazing (the mod-maker is russian) and installing it is a pain due to a complicated series of events that involved a spat between mod makers. Conclusion, I would go for Titanium wars, mainly because it has a larger selection of units and it makes some armies playable in multiplayer, However if you are not after balanced and just want to feild the largest army imagenable and do silly things. go for Apocolypse. In short; Get the game. For The Emperor, For the Dark gods, For the Greater Good, whatever battle cry you so choose, but mod it. get a few friends together, get them the game, get them the mods and proceed to smash titans against each other.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												If you have any interest in strategy games, you need to play this. Preferrably with all of the other expansions.This is a real-time strategy game. Not a big game of rock-paper-scissors (ala C&C, which I do love as well), or who-can-make-the-most-the-fastest (ala Starcraft, less love but more hours in my younger days).The campaigns are pretty good. I especially enjoyed Winter Assualt, despite it being very short. Call me a sucker for hopeless military stories. Soulstorm is better, though. It plays like a board game, taking over the planet, battling other factions. You win a battle, you take some land and get bonuses later. You lose, you wait until the next turn and plan your next move. Then move in and play what I think (because this is a review) is the best RTS experience since...well, nothing else I've played really matches it.Despite the huge number of different armies availible with all expansions, everything is pretty well balanced. Everything caters to different players. How do a bunch of Orks beat a bunch of Space Marines, or a group of Tau beat some Eldar? You have to figure it out. The same thing doesn't work against everyone. And when you have an eight-player free-for-all, what do you do? Endless options, endless replayability.It's the 41st Milenium and let's hope war indeed never changes.
