												Did you find yourself playing the highly recommended Dawn of War: Dark Crusade, but wanting more? How about THREE TIMES AS LONG loading screens, and more pixellation of textures? It's the same game as Dark Crusade with the cool meta-map feature, but this time all the mission objectives are uninspired whenever they're not like pulling rotten teeth out of a screaming child's mouth. And the new air units are "fun" if you find "poorly thought out, poorly balanced, obviously not designed for this engine" things fun!The only reason to recommend this is that one of the two new factions you get to play as are Nun Space Marines with flamethrowers. Posted: December 29, 2014
												Dawn Of War Soulstorm is without doubt my favourite game of all time, the music is atmospheric and catchy and me and my friends have spent many an afternoon singing along to the different musical themes which go with each specific race. The Campaign is set across four worlds with a huge variation of terrains. The gameplay is very fun and it is still challenging for someone who's been playing this game for many years. For a Warhammer 40K fan there's little I find more exciting than running my 40K army at another army. This game adds two new armies, the Dark Eldar and the Sisters of Battle. The Dark Eldar are most likely my favourite race (This is the army I collect) and I feel they add a good new gameplay option with the collection of souls. The Sisters of Battle aren't really my cup of tea, but hey can be very difficult to defeat. I highly recommend thi game to any 40K fans or anyone else who likes creating a awesome army. I would also recommend downloading the Ultimate Apocalypse mod from this link http://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-mod as it creates massive epic battles with Titans! Thanks for reading! From your friendly neighbourhood Splenderman

												This is the best DoW yet. It builds off the great open campaign of Dark Crusade, this time making your domination interplanetary. Plus, we get two new factions, to boot. The Sisters of Battle are some bad ♥♥♥♥♥es, I tell you. Sure, they're fanatics, but purging everything with endless flames is oddly cathartic.+9 factions to choose from, so while the campaign is basically the same for all of them, each faction is pretty unique and interesting. Well, the Dark Eldar aren't exactly unique, but they are kind of funny being an evil incarnation of Hedonism Bot in horde form.+The story is good for an RTS, and isn't riddled with overly long cutscenes like the base game+Scenery is vast seeing as you have 4 planets (and 3 moons) to work through.+One playthru took me over 22 hours, so it's worth your money.-Pathfinding is still laughably terrible. I had hoped by now it would be fixed, but I guess that was too much to ask. It requires a lot of micromanagement, and will lead to you taking a lot of excess damage at times.-Graphics are dated, but that is to be expected, and it hardly makes the game unplayable. My biggest gripe is it can be difficult to command a large army when you can't zoom out very far.-Warhammers are more prevalent than TDC, but still not 40K worth, so unacceptable, TBQH.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Having very little experience of Warhammer 40,000 as a tabletop game, I am not going down the road of making any sort of analogy nor comparison. While it may be a strange idea to some, over the years I have had the constant barrage of "Oh, it's nothing like the tabletop game, you know." despite me not having claimed otherwise. Instead I will evaluate its merit as an RPG. I will note at this point that I have also played vanilla Dawn of War and the preceding expansions Winter Assault and Dark Crusade.On first coming to this game I found it very easy to pick up. With most races simply having the two basic resources, requisition and power, it was easy enough to settle into the tempo of gameplay. Requisition is collected by taking and holding control points (so no messy resource gathering) and power by building generators anywhere you control. The races each have their own distinct styles of warfare, but when broken down to basics they all follow the same pattern with unit types consistent across all races, so understanding what to make when and how to attack/counterattack is simple. However, the technology trees make advancement slightly different, and tactics must be adapted. Some races have unique benefits and requirements, such as the Orks requiring you to fill the Waaaaaargh! meter to progressively increase the population cap and develop improvements, or the Dark Eldar who gain powers as they consume the souls of fallen enemy troops. The differences make gameplay refreshing when playing as or against the different races.The battlefields themselves are well designed for balance (for skirmishes) or to challenge your leadership (for the campaign), with plenty of terrain variations that may help or hinder your troops advancement and survivability in a firefight. The environments too are well varied for visual and, to some extent, tactical enhancement with a healthy mix of wastelands, forests, swamps and cities from across the galaxy to whet your appetite. The campaign is reasonable, but not great, and sees you vying for control of a star system (I won't spoil it) against each of the other races. There are several tactical objectives that can even the odds before you invade a territory Risk-style should you take it. If you have played the Dark Crusade campaign then there's nothing much new with the cinematic-style endgame fights when you strike an enemy's capital, which are actually more structured scenarios than those of regular territory invasions, along with the obligatory cut-scenes.There's a decent amount of customisation available throughout, with the in-built Army Painter allowing you to do virtually what would take hours of laborious armwork and make a mess of your room/shed/garage. It has to be said, there is a certain sense of accomplishment seeing your custom flag being raised as you capture a control point. What I do find to be absent is a map editor, so in that respect customisation is a tiny bit limited, and the skirmish maps are all pre-built with no randomisation beyond your starting position (which makes little difference on a symmetrical-ish map).From a graphics standpoint the game is presented very well, with plenty of satisfying and beefy explosions, eerily beautiful plasma bolts and las beams flying around (The Baneblade in particular is especially good at showing these off) and, depending on your particular chipsets (mine not being too spectacular at the minute), the game is easily one of the prettier RTSs around, even now. The AI is decent, although bumbling on easier settings, and should provide a challenge to every skillset.In short;FOR : Simple to pick up, challenging to master. Custom armies. Good graphics, even by today's standards. Nice soundtrack.AGAINST : Limited customisation. Pre-built arenas. Not very engaging campaign (compared to previous iterations).Overall, despite its flaws, I would certainly reccomend you at least try this game. I find it to be enjoyable and quite addictive!

Posted: May 30, 2014
												Good, not great, but good enough to play over and over (maybe 8.5/10). Soulstorm was one of the last time that DLC (or expansion as it was called back then) was truly worth it (instead of paying for hidden locked content so common these days). Still, it was not as revolutionary to the franchise as Dark Crusade was or even as good as the first game was.The Good:The 2 new factions feel distinct from the rest, especially with their special powers. The AI definitely had improved, especially in campaign (being used to the one in Dark Crusade, the AI did surprise me when I played the campaign - no more steamrolling with 3 Guardsmen squads on easy) and the balance has been somewhat restored (e.g. Space Marine Squad with max. 4 heavy weapons and Imperial Guard can now have 5 heavy weapons per squad).The Acceptable:I have conflicting feeling about the campaign. It was pretty much the same campaign like Dark Crusade, except on a planetary system but they introduced some fun innovations like the webway portal provinces, supply lines and stronghold bonuses - all which I strongly approve. But it wasn't long into the campaign before I realized how lazy the storytelling was; the dialogues were minimal (no more taunting in the beginning or after some objectives were completed in the Stronghold missions), awkward and stiff and the characters were forgettable at most. Some cutscenes were so poorly done that you wonder if they use first-year interns to do it.The Bad:Terrible voice acting that gave rise to the legend of METHUL BAWKSES, SPHESS MEHREENS and THE EMPRAH (although the new update restored the in-game voices to the good ones from Dark Crusade for some units (SM Force Commander has Thule's, Chaos Lord has Eliphas' [unfortunately they forgot to put Sindri back]), somewhat correcting this problem). Air units, which I was initially excited about, can really destroy the rebalanced gameplay; the Tau Barracuda can wreck an entire base on its own, the Ork Bomma is similarly devastating to infantry and Space Marines will only need the Land Speeder Tempest en masse).

My only two main gripes with the expansion are that the computer A.I. will often try to build smaller secondary bases when on the run making battles take too long.  And the stronghold mission against the Sisters of battle is an unreasonable pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Its not hard just annoying because you have to destroy three statues while fending of a near invunerable Monsterous creature. That being said if you liked Dawn of War up to this point then this breaths in a few more hours of life into the game.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												Although growing old in years, DoW is a landmark RTS and is the best WH40K game that has been made in terms of sheer content and variety. Whilst the campaign is lacklustre, having 9 races that play very differently is an incredible feat, backed up by just how much extra content you can find from the mod scene. The game was launched with ease of modding in mind and as such you can massively expand the game into the most comprehensive WH40K game that has ever been made, and possibly will ever be.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												This game in itself is very mediocre. It's an alright game, worth the money, and it can keep you entertained for a few hours. The campaign itself didn't really do it for me, the first DoW campaign was way better. Skirmish is really fun though.The balance between the races are really broken. The Tau for example don't have turrets or mines, so though they have a strong offence, their defence is is lacking and unless you constantly have an army at your disposal you're pretty much doomed. The IG is pretty much overpowered as their soldiers may be weak, but there are a lot of them, and they're quick to train and cheap as well.If you download and install the Ultimate Apocalypse mod however, this game instantly becomes a masterpiece. It fixes all problem (or most) such as the lack of turrets for the tau, and they even created their very own models! Combine it with the Tyranid mod and you get tyranids as an additional army, though I personally don't enjoy them too much.Highly recommended.

Posted: April 5, 2013
												A lot of people know Soulstorm by "SPESS MEHREENS", "METAL BAWKSES" and such. And in all fairness, if there was one thing I would critique Soulstorm for other than lack of polish, it is occasionally train-wreck level off-kilter VA work.However, occasional VA disaster aside, I would consider Soulstorm a flawed, yet still highly interesting gem. The campaign system, while no larger than Dark Crusade's, is deeper from the introduction of Webway travel and a better slew of racial bonuses on the campaign map (no more Necrons with Fury nonsense  on Turn 1, looking at you, DC) and both the new races are at the least of a different variety to the others in the game with viable differing strategies. The introduction of flyers adds at least in part another element of power-play to the game by acting as an extra combat element on the attack and the defence. Would I recommend Soulstorm for £40? No. But for the asking price offered, I would absolutely encourage people to round out the DoW 1 collection and see what Soulstorm has to offer. You might be as surprised as me.

Posted: March 31, 2016
												There is but one thing that I must disagree with in this game, and that is the incredibly low perspective. It nearly leaves my eyes sore staring at my screen too long, and yet I still find myself pouring hours into the game. There is just something so captivating to me about painting an army to my specific tastes, then sending them to battle against a cornucopia of different enemies, be it the long-range Tau or the resilient and slow moving Necrons, the game does well to offer variety in nearly every regard. There are nine seperate factions to play as, each is very independant of the other, and rarely is something ever copied or re-used. The voice acting is especially well done, and be it the cry for help or a taunt thrown towards the enemy, each line is spoken with skill and care for the character they are representing. I do, in fact, prefer the previous DLC, Dawn of War: The Dark Crusade's campaign, but then the multiplayer in any RTS game I have ever played has never felt quite as different as this specific title. Finally, I must say that if you are looking for an strategy game with serious a range of different factions with recognizable similarities, then there may be no better title that Dawn of War: Soulstorm. Thank you for reading, and best of days for you.

Posted: May 14, 2016
												Wether your playing this game as a standalone or playing with the base games it will give you hours of playtime. Even so it is best played with the core game and the Winter assault and Dark Crusade expansions.Pros:- Good selection of playable factions. - Decent amount of maps of varying sizes.- Cood campaign that is semi-linear allowing you to choose which battles you play depending on which faction you choose.- Each faction has its own play style, strenghts, and weaknesses.- Can make your own colour schemes for use in skirmish and multiplayer modes.Cons:- Most of the factions have a very rigid playstyles.- Some factions have limited or nearly no counters to others so are easily defeated. (Stealth being the worst offender for some of the factions)- Campaign isn't really a story, but more a multi-battle system with a back story for each faction's involvement.

Posted: February 1, 2016
												Warhammer 40,000. This universe is where dreams come true in the form of bloodshed and misery! Enjoy the fleeting moments of silence as you gaze into the Fog Of War and suddenly, a Bloodthirster bull-rushes your men and tosses them into the air, using them for human baseballs (No, really, they do). Call upon your Predator tanks and yet you still cannot best this beast, when suddenly, your Force Commander charges in, holy hammer swinging, and jumps onto the beast's head and rides it into submission, then pounds it back into the underworld (Warp) ((Also happens, seriously, you can witness this)) Or... you could use the powers of the Warp yourself (And the powers of ModDB) to gain the advantage and send in more Bloodthirsters! (Seriously the No Limit mod makes this game that much more fun) The total anarchy of the combat and the brutality of the 'Sync-Kills' make up for the lack of up-to-date graphics. You REALLY need this game, or get Dark Crusade! Just don't get the older ones, not worth the money unless you want the story. GET. THIS. Game.

Posted: November 11, 2016
												The penultimate entry in the Dawn of War One sub-series, Soulstorm offers a freeform campaign much like Dark Crusade, but has vast improvements along with the two new factions being thrown into the mix. The "special" ability regions of Dark Crusade are now bundled in with the Strongholds, making them far more important and freeing up the land to hold more varied honor guard units.In regards to the battles, every faction has gained a new unit. The Necrons have gained access to another god, The Deciever, while everyone else has gained a flying unit (Attack Scarabs becoming one) capable of flying over any terrain at high speeds while melee units shake their sluggas towards the sky in frustration.

												I Really like this game, A LOT! Storming the battlefield with space marines or blowing open chaos with tau plasma fire is great fun, my only complaint is that the zoomout for the base game is not good, and doesn't represent the scale I think relic was going for. However, there is a mod to add additional camera zoomout.Along with the zoomout mod, there is another mod which is the main reason I have played this game for over 500 hours is Ultimate Apocalypse, a glorious addition to Soulstorm which adds in three new races (adding up to 12 races counting the 9 ones already in the game, and the 3 new ones in UA) and many, many new units and even titans! Along with this, the ability to zoom out much farther is very nice. Especially for me, as I am a player who loves to use artillery such as basilisks or whirlwinds, and the extra zoomout range can help you see what exactly you are shooting at. Overall The expansion itself is great, with the multi-planet campaign and adding in the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar, the one problem I have with this expansion, and game as a whole is the zoomout and the fact that many of the smaller maps don't give you enough room to build your base up properly, bringing the game down to a 9/10. With mods though, you can play this game for hours (as I have) and with UA in particular, I give this game a 10/10. In fact, I might be playing this game right now.
